146915264.review:
Steam really needs a Neutral position.

Forward to the Sky is neither hot garbage, nor is it a hidden gem. It is decidedly "meh" all around.

In a nutshell it is a 3D puzzle-platformer with barely any puzzle and somewhat finicky platforming. It does contain some combat in the form of little mooks you occasionally have to mop up. The plot revolves around an unnamed princess seeking to stop an unnamed witch, with little vignettes between chapters.

The controls for combat are not ideal, cause dodging is either leaping backwards or jumping forwards (into the sky) often leading to you falling over the side. You have combos that will typically miss cause there is no locking onto enemies. If anything, the dodging works better for the platforming in certain situations.

If the two characters begin talking, just stop playing until they finish or you risk missing what's being said.

There [i]is[/i] a single boss at the end of the game, and it's mediocre. However, the plot is at least wrapped up with a conclusion. To get the most out of the meager story you [b]must[/b] collect all the little gems in every stage. They are typically not hard to find, however, just sometimes annoying to reach.

I won't tell anyone to go out of their way to play this, but if you can get it for like a buck or something then knock yourself out. I've certainly played worse.

136547844.review:
Forward to the Sky is an Action J Style platformer.

STORY: 3/10
Personally, the story is dull, uninteresting, and lacking in depth. It failed to keep me engaged, with too much filler and flutter, and it felt as though I was playing through a story that had no real substance. I was not invested in completing the level to find out the next part of the story. As with anything, there is room to worsen.

GAMEPLAY: 3/10
You play a princess in a 3rd person action platformer. I personally had issues using the gamepad from the start, and it definitely does not work properly. The goal is to complete the level, and collecting all of the crystals is not worth the effort.

DIFFICULTY: 3/10
If you plan on being an achievement completionist, you should expect this game to last you longer than it should. For me, the puzzles were frustratingly difficult, and I found myself having to go back and forth in some areas too many times to completely understand some of them. When you complete the puzzle, you will feel negative for wasting your time. The combat of the game is terrible; you will face a handful of different skeletons with varying abilities, all will frustrate you; the combat is weak and leaves you with nothing but disappointment.

TECHNICAL: 2/10
When first launching the game, the menus confused me, clicking each one of them takes you to a different part of configuration or tutorial, and eventually will start the game. I would have personally liked if the menus were a bit more intuitive, but that's too much to ask for in this poorly designed game. Performance was meh, with a shaky 30fps and constant dips in graphics. Some of the sounds, like a whistle for the balloon when you die can get annoying; I would prefer something less irritating.

CONCLUSION
Not recommended gameplay for a platformer that fails to deliver anything remotely interesting, with meh graphics and a forgettable story. 3/10

Forward to the Sky es un juego de aventuras y plataformas que ofrece una jugabilidad divertida y emocionante. Aunque la jugabilidad puede parecer simple, el juego sigue siendo una experiencia agradable para pasar el rato.

La banda sonora es decente, aunque no es el aspecto más destacado del juego. La falta de más niveles y enemigos puede ser un poco decepcionante, pero el juego aún logra mantener el interés del jugador gracias a los acertijos y obstáculos desafiantes.

La historia es un poco superficial y no ofrece mucha profundidad, pero eso no impide que el juego sea disfrutable. La interfaz del juego puede ser un poco complicada al principio, pero una vez que se entiende, es fácil de manejar.

Para aquellos que buscan desafíos adicionales, el juego ofrece una gran cantidad de logros para desbloquear, lo que agrega un elemento adicional de juego.

En general, aunque Forward to the Sky tiene algunas limitaciones en cuanto a su jugabilidad, historia y diseño de niveles, sigue siendo un buen juego para pasar el tiempo. Si buscas un juego de aventuras y plataformas divertido y emocionante, Forward to the Sky es una opción sólida.

Upon first glance, Forward to the Sky evokes thoughts of a typical Zelda-style adventure. The graphics, camera angles, and surrounding environments are reminiscent of such games. However, upon delving deeper, the comparison falls a bit short. While there is a storyline present, it may come across as shallow and forgettable. This may be attributed to the title's relatively short length.

The gameplay features simple hack-and-slash mechanics, along with some challenging jumps and puzzles that require skill. The graphics are stunning, and the soundtrack and sound effects are satisfactory. However, the voice dubbing could be considered a bit grating. A positive aspect of the game is the inclusion of trading cards and achievements, which aren't actually impossible to get.

All in all, it's still an interesting experience to say the least, and given its short length, it may be a good choice for individuals who prefer more condensed gaming experiences.

120223267.review:
If you like puzzle games, this one is... alright. There are things I like and things I don't like.

The combat is very vanilla, being that the main focus is solving the puzzles and advancing the story. The puzzles are generally simple to solve, but at times it can be a tiny bit difficult to execute exactly what you want to do (a lot of timing things and jumping at just the right second) but you don't die or take damage from falling off the edge, so you can try as many times as you want.

The voice acting is... there. They were clearly going for that "cutesy" anime style when it comes to the character design and voices, but it's annoying, and it's unnecessary how often we get dialogue from the princess just thinking out loud about the crystals and the witch. Or the princess saying things like "I'm going to get you, witch!" every 5 minutes. Other than that though, the style (visually) is kinda cute, including the skeletons.

The price isn't bad, especially since the game is a bit older. I did get it discounted by getting a coupon for completing a badge, but I wouldn't have been salty if I paid the full $8. I've paid more for worse games.

I think that, for what it is, it's not THAT bad, but I got over it after only the second level. It's not enough to keep me engaged, and as mentioned above, the voices/dialogue are annoying. I'd give it like... 5/10.

118923533.review:
Forward to the Sky is an okay casual adventure game, all right the story, A long time ago in a distant land people used to harvest magical crystals from a floating tower that made them all incredibly prosperous, but one day an evil which came and took the crystal and the tower away, that is what the history books have told, but now the tower has returned and a young princess vows to defeat the Witch and reclaim the Crystals.

Alright the likes, the story for the game is good and sweet, it had a nice fairy tale theme to it, the gameplay was okay nothing too complicated just kill the enemies an solve simple environmental puzzles. The graphics for the game were good nice and colorful with a cute anime theme to it, the levels in the game are good, it wasn't really diverse but it's substitute that with having beautiful scenery to look at and explore.

The music in the game was good nothing to grandiose or epic but genuinely sweet and fits the game very well. The characters in the game were good very adorable looking and having sweet personalities, the voice acting the game was good and can be generally adorable. The enemies in the game were okay they had a cute look to them and the boss of the game was good and was not too tough.

The puzzles in the game we're good nothing too complicated, just simple environmental puzzle, the price for the game is fair. But my favorite part of the game is after collecting 100 crystals from a level you're treated to the story revealing itself as well as getting these adorable drawings to go with the story which I found nice and adorable.

Alright the dislikes, sometimes the game can be a little frustrating like getting knocked back when hitting an environmental hazard, and I feel like the combat in the game felt like it was more of an afterthought and there was a bug or two in the game but nothing really game breaking. I also would have liked the game to have full controller support I mean you don't really need it half controller support works well, but still would have preferred the game to have full controller support.

All right now that I told you this Forward to the Sky is an okay casual adventure game, it has a good sweet story, nice and colorful graphics and good characters. So I recommend this game if you're looking for a casual adventure game you can't really go wrong with this one.

112609068.review:
This one ended up being much more entertaining than expected.

Forward To the Sky is a fun little cozy puzzle platformer where you have to traverse a set of stages as you climb towards the top of a magical tower, to reach your goal. While the puzzles/platforming tends to be on the simpler side, I was pleasantly surprised with each stage offering something different, a unique gimmick every time, bringing more variety. There is also combat involved but there isn't a lot of depth, but serves its purpose of bringing a few more obstacles in your path which admittedly isn't extremely challenging, so if you are looking for a more complex and tough puzzler, perhaps this one isn't aimed at you.. 
There is also the crystal collection. While you can complete the stages without collecting all of them, it is strongly recommended to do so, not only to unlock more of the story but to explore and engage more with exploration, the tower's puzzles and figuring out what to do.
Music is appropriately comfy and voice acting is on a similar note, simple and sometimes cheesy.
If there is one downside is that it's a vey short game and it's a shame because the devs have obviously put a lot of care in designing the stages and the puzzles and the game would only benefit with an expanded set of them.

While not mind-blowing and not sure if I could call it a "hidden gem", it is a really nice game if you want to spend a few hours of casual puzzle platforming fun.

112062518.review:
I bought this game using a coupon I got from crafting a badge on Steam. I usually don't play games like this but I read in the reviews that this was a relatively short game with some simple achievements so I thought why not, having another perfect game is kind of cool for the (low amount of) money.

I started out having a "meh" time. Combat feels a little sluggish since you can't find AND jump at the same time, you're not able to run anywhere (pressing 'shift' does something else) and I often got hit because I was still locked in another animation. The first few levels weren't particularly challenging and the voice-acting was a little too much for me. I had some trouble getting into it. 

Later on the game and levels became more fun though. I really wanted to get the '100 crystals' per level and for that you have to destroy some statues. Further into the game I came close to finishing levels with close to half of the required amount of crystals even though I thought I had been and looked everywhere. Needed to some some backtracking at times and that actually wasn't a big deal because I thought some of the level design was quite good and sometimes even challenging.

Also, I LOVED the way this game did 'checkpoints' since whenever you fall off the tower, you'll respawn into a balloon that drops you off basically right where you were before. No need to start the entire level again. 

*** Summary ***
+++
- Cheap (especially with coupon)
- Cute visuals
- Light-hearted and cozy game
- Funny puzzles and placement of statues to destroy (later on)
- Forgiving checkpoint system

---
- Over-the-top voice-acting (imo)
- Very short (finished the game in less than 3 hours and I was very slow)
- Clunky combat with less enemy variety

Bland and uninspired.

This game looks cute and passable for an indie, but that's the only good thing I can say about it, absolutely everything else is terrible. The combat is too simple and very stiff, there are no items to acquire, no weapon upgrades, no unlocks, no level ups, no skills, no nothing. You just wack the same three or four types of skeletons all game, and they all feel like slapping a wooden board, as it does when a laser, giant rock or magic hits our character, awkwardly pushing her back.

The worse tho, it has to be the dialogue. The game writing is [i]terrible[/i], it has zero subtlety, zero complexity and hammers the same idea again and again and again every few steps we make. The voice acting is not much better, as it feels unmotivated, muted, and lacking energy. Very amateurish overall and doesn't even sound the same as the SFX the character makes.

The level design and puzzles are ok-ish, a bit clunky and too easy for my taste but passable for younger audiences. Still, I feel it was a wasted opportunity as lots of the tower had hidden crevices you could get into, with nothing in them, absolutely no reward for exploring beyond the "follow the path and wack all four statues in every level".

Just an overall mediocre puzzle platformer.

102880796.review:
The Troublesome Princess wants to prove that she is not troublesome at all, so she goes out looking for trouble with the Evil Witch up in the Sky Tower. 

The story and graphics are cute, but the game is super short. There are only 5 levels, plus a final boss. Your objective is to simply to navigate and reach the end of each stage, optionally collecting 100 crystals along the way. Each level has 3 Crystal Statues (25 crystals each) and multiple enemies (usually 1 crystal per enemy, larger ones might have 2 or 3). Controls are very straightforward and battle is very easy, but you cannot heal. Each level introduces new mechanics and finding the way to the next level is not always trivial (though it is still always easy). 

Linux port was flawless, thanks for supporting the penguin! Achievements are also straighforward and well done. Plus cards! If you're looking for a short, cute and casual adventure game, you found it.

101530203.review:
[h1]Lindo.. PEEEERO... [/h1]

Un pequeño y corto juego con tintes de juego indie japones que por ratos se siente muy tosco en combate, pero por lo demás lo hace medianamente bien.

A primeras instancias el diseño de la interfaz del menú principal y pausa son muy de titulo de celular del 2012 (que no me sorprendería que tenga un port en iOS o Android) que no le sienta muy bien, de hecho otros objetos con los cuales interactuamos se sienten de tal manera. 

El gameplay es básicamente un plataformero con resolución de puzzles y un combate que podría haber sido mejor, pero que se adecúa para la sencillez de este. Contaremos con unos 6 niveles de los cuales cada uno tendrá un gimmick distinto para identificarlos, pero artísticamente se ven “iguales” y monótonos. También podremos explorar dichos niveles para descubrir zonas ocultas que nos recompensaran con mas lore sobre el mismo. Afortunadamente podremos darnos el gusto de hacerlo sin presiones ya que la penalización por perder en una zona o caernos no es tan grave y nos devuelve cerca de un área en particular.

La historia va de una princesa que tiene que matar una bruja pero luego se da cuenta que esta ultima no tiene nada de malo y que cree que es otra cosa, pero siendo honestos es pura excusa para el juego.

No llega a durar mas de 3 horas y es perfecto para pasar una tarde aburrido, pero no es un titulo que te sacara del aburrimiento o que te va a quedar en la mente por unos días. Quizás seria mejor comprarlo en una buena oferta.

theres a nice variety of puzzle platforming challenges: moving platforms, redirecting lasers, running on boulders. Each level is fresh and unique.

the goal of each level is to collect 100 crystals and reach the end of the level. 75 of the crystals are locked inside of 3 statues, while the remaining 25 are within the enemies that are scattered about the level.

unfortunately the combat is rather insubstantial, you have a 5 hit combo and a 3 hit combo, but they arent all that different in terms of how much damage they deal. you have a backstep move (mapped to left shift) that i assume is for dodging, but more often than not i wound up falling off the stage when i used it because my muscle memory kept thinking it was a sprint button. I feel the game would have been stronger if the devs removed the enemies entirely and changed the boss to include more challenging variations on the puzzle platforming challenges that were seen in previous levels.

a short and cute adventure with a serviceable but otherwise unspectacular story. some may find the voice acting annoyingly cutesy but ive always had a thing for this style.

overall i would say catch it on a sale.

90956822.review:
Forward to the Sky is a platform game with a little bit of combat and a little bit of puzzle solving.
The player controls a sword-wielding princess who is tasked with scaling a sky tower in order to defeat an evil witch, but as the princess progresses upwards through the tower, she slowly learns that the tale she's been told of the evil witch isn't quite the full truth...

The main emphasis of the game is the platforming. The player will spend most of his/her time maneuvering through the obstacles of each level. A different gimmick is introduced in each level which prevents the game from feeling stale or repetitive. There are some secret areas added into each level as well, for those who are explorers or completionists.

As the player progresses, he/she will occasionally come across a cluster of enemies or a puzzle to solve. The puzzles, for the most part, are rather intuitive, offering a simple challenge that can be overcome with a small amount of trial-and-error. There are very few puzzles that might stump the player for a few minutes or so. Combat, on the other hand, is a bit disappointing. It's pretty basic with only a few attacks and a dodge. There aren't a whole lot of enemy encounters in each level and only one boss at the end of the game, so unfortunately, this makes the world feels very empty. 

Visually, the game is beautiful to look at. The world is bright and colorful, like one might see in a fairy tale environment. The protagonist has a cute design. The background music is nice and suits a platforming game well. The voice acting, however, is average.

Overall, the game is okay. Though it is a polished game, it feels like it fell short of its full potential. It is strong in some areas, but has drawbacks in others. The game can be completed 100% in a few hours, so I leave it up to the buyer whether the full $7.99 is worth the investment. Personally, I bought this game when it was on sale, and I was happy with the purchase.

79536833.review:
[b]My playtime:[/b] 2.3h (based on Steam, 100% achievement)
[b]Grindy Achievement(s):[/b] No.
[b]Optional Achievement(s):[/b] Yes (5 achievements).
[b]Difficult Achievement(s):[/b] No.

[h1]Intro[/h1]
Initially, I thought that this is a short action RPG game where you have to clear some dungeons to finish. I thought the only downside to the game would be its short playtime, but I was completely wrong. In fact, it's more heavily focused on puzzles and precision platformers. While I'm still a fan of those genres, some things don't sit right when I played [b]Forward to the Sky[/b]. More on the review.

[b]Pros:[/b]
- Almost all dialogues are dubbed
- 6 levels with one boss fight level
- Difficult puzzles

[b]Cons:[/b]
- The hitbox of the lasers in level 5 is too large
- You still can move when you are pushing boxes
- Dialogues are being told as you explore the levels, even if there's an enemy to fight
- Poor combat mechanics

[h1]Should you buy this game?[/h1]
[b]No.[/b]
[i]There are better games than this. One example is [url=https://store.steampowered.com/app/205910/Tiny_and_Big_Grandpas_Leftovers/][b]Tiny and Big: Grandpa's Leftovers[/b][/url] ([url=https://steamcommunity.com/profiles/76561198132503739/recommended/205910]my review[/url]), which also focuses on puzzles and has longer playtime with the same offering price. It's even cheaper than this game when it's on sale.[/i]

------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
[h1]In-Depth Review[/h1]

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The main menu is the first thing that ruins my expectation when I played this game. It looks like a cheap unity game where the dev tries to slap some images with no word to it. Not only did it look terrible, but it is also confusing. It took me some time to figure out how to start the game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2292560069

Luckily, the in-game graphics are the same as the screenshots on the store page. The main character has a cute, anime-looking style with a simple, yet great-looking environment in it. It looks cheap while beautiful at the same time.

[h1]Story[/h1]
The story was told in two parts. There is a huge chunk of text that acts as a summary to the game at the beginning and end of each level and some dialogues that happen as you play the game. It seems that the dev is bad at making an attractive main menu because the summary has the same style as the main menu; it also looks like one of those cheap games.

While the in-game dialogue looks great with the beautiful dialogue text and voice dub in every dialogue, it becomes annoying as time passes because the character doesn't know when to stop. She always talks, even if there are monsters that I had to beat. If you ask me whether I had to listen to the pointless dialogue or focus on killing the monsters, there's no way I wouldn't choose the latter one.

[h1]The Game[/h1]
[b]Combat[/b]
To be honest, the combat feels more like hack and slash rather than action RPG. You can use left or right mouse click to attack, space to dash, and shift to dodge backward. Although the game seems to differentiate between left and right mouse click attacks, the difference isn't noticeable to me as I just needed to mash my mouse clicks to defeat the enemies. Dashing forward and rolling backward are also useless that I never paid attention to them.

Although enemies are very easy on the first level, more variations and stronger enemies will be available on the next few levels. You still need to spam mouse click to defeat them, although you might want to prioritize the stronger enemies first. Since the dodge backward mechanic is counterintuitive and there's no other way to dodge enemies' attack, you're bound to take damage in each fight. Luckily, I finished all levels on my first try despite me always almost running out of health. I'm sure wouldn't enjoy the game this much if I had to die and restart the game again from the beginning.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2292560037

There is a boss fight at the last level where you must figure out the boss' attack patterns to defeat. While I find this to be the most satisfying combat the game has to offer, it took me a while to realize that my attack is effective towards the boss. The boss doesn't move at all when I was attacking that I thought that I wasn't dealing damage.

[b]Puzzles[/b]
The game relies heavily on puzzles in two of the levels. While the first one is quite obvious, it took me a while to understand how the second one works. There is no tutorial or whatsoever that can help you to figure out the confusing mechanic either. However, it becomes one of my most favorite levels after I learned it due to its challenging difficulty.

[b]Platformer[/b]
You'll need to jump through platforms, sometimes within a time limit, to reach the other side of the road. However, I found it hard to control where to land whenever I'm taking a long leap to finish the run more efficiently; I ended up ditching the idea and had to be very careful to make sure that I landed correctly whenever I jump. Luckily, the game doesn't give any penalties if you fail the jump; you will respawn close to where you fall so you won't waste time walking to the same spot again.

There is still one more problem though. One of the levels requires you to dodge a laser while moving. However, the laser seems to have a larger hitbox than it seems, making it hard to figure where to actually move. There is even an occasion where you must move close to moving lasers that it seems to be impossible to get through without getting hit.

[b]Difficulty and Length[/b]
The game has 6 levels in total. Each level has unique mechanics although your objective is still the same: to reach the goal. There is also an additional objective where you need to collect 100 crystals, which can be found by clearing everything in the dungeon, to unlock the full story. Doing so is tricky though as some crystals are well hidden, giving more challenge to the game.

https://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=2292560100

The game is not hard to beat although I admit that I was always close to death whenever I finished the levels. Each level can be finished in less than 30 minutes and I finished the game at 2.3h after replaying the first level once because I didn't collect enough crystals to unlock the story. The game seems to only provide a save for level completion that you must restart the level again from the beginning if you want to collect the missing crystals.

[b]Problems[/b]
I just find it odd that the game decides to let my character move whenever I was pushing boxes. I needed to reposition my character several times because of this.

[h1]Specs[/h1]
Intel Core i5-9300H 2.40GHz, 8GB RAM, NVIDIA GeForce GTX 1650

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Despite it being marketed as an action RPG, there aren't many enemies to beat, and combat isn't what I remember doing the most in the game. The only combat that is memorable is the final boss level which also has its issues. In fact, the difficult puzzle level still remains in my mind due to how enjoyable it is. However, with so many lackluster mechanics that the game has, I don't think I can recommend this game, especially since there are better games out there with longer playtime and cheaper price.

74397942.review:
Fun hack-and-slash with 3D-anime graphic.
Simple combat system  by using the ASWD + LMB and RMB on your mouse only.
English voice actiing.
So-so story.
Adding extra puzzle elements to the environment makes it more challenging to solve the stage.
No save point, but is pretty generous with always surviving you at certain checkpoints.
Easy to understand mission and objectives, but could be VERY repetitive. Then again there's only 6 stages to begin with. Nothing much to explore.
There're a total of 6 stages so it's a pretty short gameplay, for those who wants to buy the game, buy it whenever you feel it's the right time for you so you can say it's 'worth it".


Cons:
- Main Menu UI is hard to distinguish from the background
- Playing one stage is enough to leave me with motion sickness with the (very) swift movement of camera rotation and such. The camera doesn't seem to rotate that smoothly. Jittering when running on stairs doesn't help either.
- Since every platform looks the same, and the camera is rotating in a weird way, it's actually hard to see the bigger picture of the map
- Needs map, in addition to previous points
- Needs target lock so we know if we're bashing on the right enemies.
- Needs enemy HP. This is optional, because I know some RPG games which doesn't implement this, and can still play nicely, BUT those games at least show a reaction from the enemy when getting hit, so we know we actually dealt some damages at them.
- Needs better effect/SFX and animation to show damage dealt to the enemies. Right now it feels like I'm hitting a stone.

Conclusion: 6 stages with old UI and gameplay which of course can't be on par to games these days. I'll repeat: buy the game whenever the price seems right to you considering the short gameplay and limited mechanics it offers..

To defeat the evil cute witch....thats it.

66227785.review:
Forward to the Sky is a rather interesting short game. The game has an interesting visual style, while not unique, it sure doesn't lack a beautiful world. The puzzles are interactive and interesting, and the game even has a simplistic combat system in the game. 
The game is a charming in look and gameplay. The game has no tutorial, but the game is simple enough to pick up without it. The game is rather relaxing in difficulty, but the final boss did become somewhat difficult if you are playing sloppily. The combat system even has nice touches that are not in other systems, like a move to retreat backwards, despite its shortcomings in other combat areas.
The limited story is a rather bittersweet one, the main story is told to you as a reward for collecting every gem in each stage, which count twenty-five enemies and three statues. 
The world is varied in puzzles, several custom set pieces are used in each level, while many only stay in one stage, the variety is interesting.
However, this is an eight dollar game, so there are bound to be issues. The game's control feel floaty at times, the dialogue is a bit off sounding in section, and some 'Scripted' sections require input with no indication of  what and how until you fall into the void, though the game does not punish you for falling down. 
Overall, these are issues one would expect in a game of the price range. The game is great overall and I would recommend you check it out if you feel like spending an afternoon playing a game.

65880076.review:
7/10 - Good

Oh, this is downright adorable. Forward to the Sky is a platforming game in 3D, where you control a very zealous young Princess, who set off in her hot air balloon to scale a crystal tower and defeat the resident witch!

It’s charming! Endearingly so. The Princess is naïve, but her heart is in the right place. You scale six levels of the tower, chopping away at skeleton foes and smashing statues to collect crystals. Collect 100 at a level and it reveals the full story for you. Collect fewer than 100 and you get half the story or just one part of the story. (They don’t drop individually, they drop in clusters of 10/25, so it’s not a chore.)

As you progress the young Princess debates with the witch as the lore becomes more revealing.

It’s pretty good. Gameplay is fairly simple platforming and you swing and hack at the skeletons, though combat is a minor and trivial part of the game. It is probably a great game for kids to play, but it isn’t perfect.

Some issues are floaty controls, which can make jumping sections tricky and a rather unrefined combat system. Those two issues aside, the game is short and the difficulty is trivial. If you fall off a platform for example, you don’t die, it just rescues you in the hot air balloon. You only have to restart the level if your health expires and you’re given 1,000 hit points, which is fairly generous. It is however, appropriately priced at a mere £5 and you can probably get this for less at places like Fanatical.

Definitely a good game and a little hidden gem to try out if you ever get the time. Sensible gamers should be able to finish it in two hours and a bit.

From Forward to the Sky, I was expecting a cute little 3D Zelda-like game, with a nice little story, pleasing artstyle, and an adorable looking princess as a playable character... but, unfortunately, the game doesn't manage to be actually good...

More than the 3D action RPG that I expected, this is more of a 3D platforming puzzler... and a very basic at that. The controls are slow and heavy, with a really clunky jump that's usually quite hard to land. The mechanics require hitting switches, stepping on bottons, pushing boxes, and combat; and about these last two...
[list]
[*][b]Pushing boxes feels awful![/b] As clunky as the original Half-Life, but slower and much more unprecise.
[*][b]The combat is dreadful![/b] A 4 hit slash combo, 3 hit stab combo, and a dodge. Sounds fine, but you'll most likely not be able to land the stab, you usually have no time to dodge attacks, and many enemies can break your combo consistently.

The story is cute, but extremely simple... the same goes for the main character... actually, the same goes for the entire game: ok-ish, but not good. With a huge sale, this may be a nice little title to try out... but to me at least, this was extremely disappointing...

This is a derpy little collectathon game, relying mostly on 3D platforming and puzzle elements.  You can play through the game without collecting any of the crystals, but the game rewards players with story equivalent to what they collect.  Each of the 6 levels has 3 statues that give out 25 crystals each, and enemies that give out varying crystals, equivalent to a total of 25 crystals per level, such that there are 100 crystals to collect per level (or... 3 statues to collect + enemies to kill).  The story is not deep whatsoever, so if you can't find a statue, you're not really missing out on much.

The gameplay is a little clunky, and it's very short and linear for a collectathon, leaving a bit to be desired.  I wouldn't recommend buying this game for full price given these two factors, but it's enjoyable enough, especially if you like casual collectathons or 3D platformers.

I try to be indepth with reviews but I just can't really do that here, Forward to the Sky has no content to really talk about and really shoddy mechanics to boot.

The story and voice acting are weak anime tropes, but the voice acting adds another layer of amateur level cringe on to make things even worse. I did enjoy the setting of the game, being up in the clouds on mossy white stone work and seeing how things would change from one level to another was somewhat interesting, but the level design itself is pretty lackluster and unimpressive. There was a vision there, but the actually development seems to be missing the talent required to make that vision something really good.

The gameplay is the worst part though, combat feels sluggish and unsatisfying as you beat up skeletons that vary little over and over though luckily there isn't much combat to do. However you'll be doing a fair bit of platforming over the 6 short levels and it's terrible, because once you start moving in the air there's no way to stop your character from moving in a direction, so if you're high above what you want to land on you'll be doing a dance of going back and forth trying to stay above your landing zone so you don't drift away. None of the platforming in the game is hard, but the awful controls in the air make things a lot worse than they should be.

By the time you hit the end of the game, which took an hour for me and I got all of the collectibles, you'll probably be pretty bored and excited to uninstall the game and never think about it again. That's what I'm going to do.

50700400.review:
A pretty simple and short (a couple of hours) semi-casual action puzzle platformer (think older Zelda dungeons). Jumping, pushing boxes, messing with switches that move platforms/doors/obstacles. Only six levels (but each are decently long) where you climb the tower and collect the 100 crystals that drop from enemies (1 each, 25 enemies) and statues (25 each, 3 statues tucked away in optional/out-of-the-way areas). You have 1000 HP to take damage from enemies and obstacles (and luckily falling off the tower doesn't harm  you) so you can take a good amount of hits. However, you can't slack off too much because there's no way to restore HP and losing it all means you start the whole level over. I took combat too casually (just ran towards and slashed enemies) and got burnt by the big mage in the 4th level who just summons crystals next to them and freezes you in place for the other enemies. The solution: [spoiler]Just defeat everyone else first while staying outside of crystal range.[/spoiler]

The story is alright (fairy tale) but the main character is so naive?/innocent?/childish? that the dialogue is sometimes hard for me to listen to. It reminds me a bit of RWBY.

Controls are pretty simple. Directional movement, buttons to jump, backflip, and two multi-hit attacks (first attack goes for up to 5 hits and you move forward a little bit each time, second attack does a bigger lunge forwards and goes for up to 3 hits). In the tower, you attack to activate certain switches, stand on buttons, walk into (to push) boxes/rotate certain objects, and jump for platforming/dodging enemy attacks.

Worth a look if you can stand naive protagonists and want a somewhat casual and short action-platforming experience.

Other thoughts:[list]
[*] The controller is fine in-game but I couldn't figure out how to move the volume sliders without the mouse. Also, it feels a bit weird to have x360 controller use X as confirm instead of A.
[*] It's a bit annoying that you don't have a dash forwards. It feels like the fastest way to travel is to face the camera and backflip.
[*] I wish there was a jump/aerial attack. It doesn't feel great to have to land before attacking.
[*] It's nice that the game is generous/close in its placement when you fall off the tower. There is very little backtracking from my experience.
[*] When you fall off the face of the world there's a whistle as you take the air balloon back to the tower. The whistle is almost like/replaces the falling scream you'd hear in other games.
[*] I'm not 100% sure but I think that crystals are always automatically collected (you don't need to walk near them), which is nice. You don't need to worry about defeating enemies near the edge and the crystals falling off the world or randomly missing a crystal you should have gotten.
[*] It's nice that you unlock shortcuts between parts of the level in case you missed a statue and have to backtrack.
[*] While the camera is normally fine, I wish you could zoom out or detach the camera. There's one small part where you walk upside-down and I didn't like the how the camera faced the ceiling.
[*] The coloring/shading of her face is static so close-up it looks kind of like she's wearing a mask/face paint.
[*] The air balloon is so handy that you'd think you would be able to just use it to climb and skip the whole tower.
[*] The story ending is only okay. [spoiler]The solution to isolation is to go stay in an isolated place to avoid contact? I guess one person is better than no contact.[/spoiler]

50532495.review:
[h1][b]Cute Little Platofrmer[/b][/h1]

[h1]Quick Version[/h1]

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
[*]Cute graphics, characters, voices, and story
[*]Chilled and relaxing experience
[*]Could quite easily 100%, for anyone interested in achievements (can be done in a single play-through)
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
[*]No real replay value
[*]Incredibly short
[/list]

[h1]Slightly Longer Version:[/h1]

I won't write much because I'd risk my review being longer than the actual game. The game is incredibly short. I finished it in little over an hour, and would've likely got 100% Steam achievements with an extra 15-20 minutes.

Everything in the game is cute; the story, the protagonist, the graphics, the voices.. Even the enemies are pretty cute. It's a pretty nice looking game and the platform elements, although nothing new or special to platformers, give a small challenge to those playing.

It's a very chilled experience, maybe too chilled. Nothing is particularly difficult or stressful. The combat is very basic. All you really need to do is mash your left and/or right mouse buttons and you'll be fine. You do have some form of dodge, but it's pretty redundant.

It's a nice looking game, and would likely be fine for a young child starting off in the world of gaming. For anybody else, it's just simple and boring (and I'm usually a fan of simplicity). If it's on sale, or in a bundle and you want to kill and hour, then you may want to try the game, but I can't justify getting it at full price.

You can also find my review on [url=https://wetheplayers.com/reviews/gawain-s-forward-to-the-sky-review]We The Players[/url].[/quote]

50397613.review: The game overall was fun. A small adventure. Don't expect to many bells and whistles from it. There were certain aspects that were great and others a bit challenging.

50288136.review:
A very short game, which is kinda cute, but also low-quality.

■■■ Gameplay ■■■
The gameplay is very simplistic mix of sword slashing, platforming, and some light puzzles. While controlling your character you can jump, attack and dodge. The game is split up in 6 chapters, and most of them have their own theme and puzzle type. Most of them aren't that much fun to play trough however; the combat is very clunky and doesn't feel satisfying at all, the puzzles are very easy, and the world design is confusing at times. All just feels very low quality, and as a bad example of game design.

■■■ Visual style & Graphics ■■■
The visual style is cute and colorful, and while the character model of the princess is very cute, most of the assets and textures used in the levels don't look very pretty. Everything is very clearly grid-based. The game also didn't run the best, despite running it on a GTX1060 and i7.

■■■ Music, SFX & Voice ■■■
I didn't like the music in this game, it's just not good. Very low sound quality, but also very uninteresting composition, just some random MIDI tracks that seemed to be thrown into the game. The loop points are also very noticeable. Sound effects are just sh*t, they sound bad, the volume is all over the place, and they just make the game feel even cheaper. The voice acting sounds kinda amateuristic, and there are some problems with the timing of the lines, but i guess the voices used are pretty cute. 

■■■ Story ■■■
This game has a very basic story, just as a tool to glue the levels together. You will get a piece of story with every level you play, but it's really not that interesting. The execution is just not good, but i guess if you can see it as a very simple children's story, it has a tiny bit of charm. The game duration about 2 hours to complete everything, so very short.

■■■ Technical & Bugs ■■■
Bad. Didn't run well, i heard loop points everywhere, the volume of sound effects is all over the place, though i can't remember having any crashes.

Maybe pick this up for 1,- as a light snack, but don't expect anything great.

50084006.review:
*If you're going to play this, play it with a mouse and keyboard, not a controller - much better experience. Camera control is ridiculously slow and choppy with controller, mouse is much more fluid.

... Not a good game, gets a little better after the first two chapters (out of 6). First chapter has the worst graphics, with textures that look lifted from Steam Greenlight titles, and the most boring puzzles. The combat is imprecise, with only two combos to cycle through mindlessly. No attacking while jumping. Really short game, so not much combat to be had, thank the devs. Air jumping puzzles in Ch.3 highlights the game's difficulties with its controls and Light crystal puzzles in Ch. 4 have some jumps in logic that make little sense. Appreciated the gravity flip in Ch.3 but not much is done with it. Spike traps in Ch.1-2 are not precisely timed and are very annoying.

Game is really for little kids, but then the puzzles ramp up in difficulty without warning before getting easy again later - that's a big minus. Otherwise, this is just too terrible a game for older gamers. There's a barebones story about a headstrong princess who wants people's approval so chooses to climb the Witch's Tower, vowing to defeat this "evil" witch, but finding that there's more to the witch than the legends say. Starting health is somewhat generous and platforming fails are met with immediate respawn nearby with no penalties. But damage amount taken is arbitrary and unpredictable.

Voice acting (English) runs the gamut from absolutely horrible to barely acceptable. When translating the lines back into Japanese in my head, it still doesn't inspire much faith in the game's writing staff. 

Character model is flat, though her ribbons bounce when moving and hair flap a little when falling. Upskirt views with some mature (?) underwear are possible in some sections or when free-falling, nothing to write home about but might catch you off guard if unfamiliar with the way Japanese pop culture treats girls' panties. Their faces are frozen and the faces have an odd curvature to them upon closer inspection. The promotional art for the game is far better than any of the 3D art you will find in this game. There's a little bit of art between chapters that play with an unlockable cutscene if you collect all 100 crystals in a chapter (25x3 from "hidden" statues and 25 from a mix of enemies), and therein lies much of the game's narrative as well.

I can't recommend this to adults or to kids - there's much better stuff out there just waiting to be played - heck, buy a secondhand Nintendo 64 and play some Banjo Kazooie games - still lightyears ahead of this game.

49881265.review:
Forward to The Sky was recently featured in a very cheap bundle, so the sudden negative reviews are likely coming from people who would have never played this genre or bought this game otherwise. So take recent reviews with a grain of salt. 

As for the game, it’s super adorable and not demanding at all graphics wise, and is a pure platforming puzzler. If you aren’t good with precise jumps and aligning yourself in platforms, you will HATE this. From like chapter four and onwards, this game requires a lot of precise movements. I found chapter four to be particularly frustrating, but not because of platforming----the puzzle for that level was just crazy. I didn’t really struggle anywhere else, but puzzle platformers are one of my all time favorite genres and I play them quite often. 

This game has six chapters and within the chapter your goal is to go forward to the sky, up to your air balloon and off to the next level. You also need to defeat various enemies and find three hidden statues in each level, with the statues usually involving some really fun puzzles. The final chapter is a boss fight and a great conclusion to the story, I wasn’t expecting this game to feature a sweet boss fight but really impressed that it did. 

My only complaint with this game is the voice acting, as someone who has an actual high voice, listening to a voice actress fake one for hours is really, really annoying and straining on the ears. So I played this game on silent. Not sure how the the voice acting is in other languages, but the English voice acting is terrible. 

Also, with a lot of recent negative reviews, I see people complaining about framedrops and I can say I played this game while watching livestreams and was at 60fps the entire time, didn’t have a single stutter or lag in the game. So, I don’t want to say it’s your setups, but man you gotta have a dookie setup to not be able to run THIS. The controls are also incredibly easy to learn and understand, and I never had a mistake that wasn’t entirely my fault.

48971622.review:
I’ve taken a lot of chances on indie games solely because of their visual style. That’s what led me to try games like Pocket Kingdom and Submerged, a mixture of art and atmosphere that evokes very specific feelings or memories in me. I couldn’t resist giving Forward to the Sky a go for that very reason, looking like something that lands square in between Studio Ghibli and Skies of Arcadia. But I know as well as anyone that it’s always a gamble when you pick up a game based on screenshots, and this one was a bust. As much as it may have nailed an aesthetic that I really appreciate, it certainly didn’t take any inspiration from better platformers or adventures.

I won’t go too deep on the story here, partly because uncovering it is a major thrust of the progression and partly because there’s not much depth anyway. The sky tower was once an important source of magical crystals for the world, but a none too neighborly witch moved in and cut off the supply for a better part of a century. The tower drifted away under her ownership but now it’s back, and a spry little princess with a poofy dress and a bigass sword is looking to seize the means of production. But not all is as it seems in this airborne edifice, and it becomes clear right from the start that the witch is hiding a greater secret. If the princess can survive the journey up to meet her, she might get a little bit more than she bargained for.

The story is told in very brief still scenes between levels, but there’s a catch. One of the magical properties of the crystals here is recording memories, and as you bash enemies and statues for the precious gems you’ll unlock more of the tale. Functionally, this means you have to collect all 100 crystals in a level to see the full scene and keep up with the story, and while they’re not exactly hidden it means the game is geared way more towards completionists. It’s also worth mentioning there’s a lot of dialog between the princess and the witch during levels, and it assumes you’ve seen the whole story scene leading into that level. This can get a little awkward if you’re not keeping up with your collecting, but not as awkward as the intensely amateur-hour voice acting.

Crystals are squirreled away in statues off the beaten path and in the bodies of rather adorable skeletons that you’ll spar with periodically during levels. Each kind of skeleton pretty much has one attack and goes down in a couple hits, so fighting them is just a matter of clicking in their direction. You have two stiff combos that will dispatch just about anything, and while they’ll get some hits on you from their own stiff attacks, you have so much health you can laugh it off. Outside the combat you’ll be scaling a big stone tower, or at least the fragments of it. Levels are really collections of rooms and platforms floating in the big blue sky, and while they might look vast and complex there’s really just one main path through each level. Take a peek at obvious platforms and you should find all the statues, and don’t bother exploring little ledges or archways because they’re just for show.

It’ll take you about 15-20 minutes to get through each level, and there are six to tackle. They tend to have different gimmicks like spinning fans or gusting winds but every single mechanic and hazard feels either poorly-implemented or janky to work with. There are mystical breezes that push you around but the glow that marks them is far too subtle, and the aforementioned fans have finicky hitboxes. More important than any of this, though is that levels are just boring. There’s not enough going on, not enough to see, and so little to the plot and combat that Forward to the Sky really lacks any kind of hook whatsoever. I could easily beat this in two hours but when I realized I was dozing off during fights in the fourth level, I knew it was time to stop.



Did you enjoy this review? I certainly hope so, and I certainly hope you'll check out more of them at https://goldplatedgames.com/ or on my [url=http://store.steampowered.com/curator/11322459/]curation page[/url]!

[h1] Notes[/h1]
There's something about the concept of progressing through a tower that I've always loved. It takes me back to Adventures of Lolo and more recently Sword Art Online. That bias may skew my review, as you can see it doesn't score all that well, but I still recommend it. 

Having finished 100% of the achievements in only 5 hours, it's a short game. On top of that the voice acting is painful and I did encounter a couple of glitches. However I feel that the only reason this game fell short of greatness is a low production budget. The level design is great and the narrative has potential. If it were longer and more polished it would have scored much higher.

Forward to the sky is a simple, short hack and slash game with decent dungeon mechanics. You can easily knock this game and its achievements out in one sitting. Playtime is roughly 2hrs.

[b]Story - 6/10[/b]

The story is very simple yet appealing, the twists are very obvious though. Story revealing through item collection is not bad.

[b]Characters - 6/10[/b]

Characters are simple but works well in this kind of story. There isn't much else to say other than the characters are relatively charming.

[b]Gameplay - 6/10[/b]

There's a variety of puzzles and it changes everytime you go through each dungeon. The controls are easy enough and the final boss fight is enjoyable.

[b]Art - 6/10[/b]

Nothing amazing, yet nothing horrible it keeps true to itself.

[b]Soundtrack - 6/10[/b]

Music is pretty and nice to listen to. It is mostly lighthearted and it comes free as DLC!

[b]Overall - 6/10[/b]

If you want a game that is fun and short then consider playing this one. Buy it on sale.

43926268.review:
tl;dr version:
Action/puzzle platformer, short, easy to 100% complete, kinda frustrating to control at times and... that's about it really.

Long version:
This caught my interest because of it's art style. Turns out, sadly the game doesn't have much else going for it.
Visuals look good, music is nice, voice acting sounds like someone reading lines without having any queues on what emotions should be represented or in which order those lines appear in the dialogue.

Gameplay is a platform puzzler, with each level being set around a specific type of puzzle. There's some combat, which is hampered by poor hit detection and by just being bland, there's some precision platforming/maneuvering that gets frustrating becuase the controls are relatively loose and like to flake out, and there's some optional puzzles to complete to get to 100% in a level. None of the puzzles are particularly complex though.
And with only 6 levels, none of which are very long, expect to see everything the game has to offer in under 2 hours if you don't skip those optional puzzles.

The game's got enough decent ideas, but none of them are very original and as noted above the execution is rather shoddy.

Much as I wanted to like this game, I'm going to recommend giving this a pass. There's too many better games around in it's genre,  especially since these 3d exploration/action/puzzle platformers have been making a bit of a comeback recently.

43747372.review:
Okay - this is a charming 3rd person, simple hack and slash, 3d dungeon romp with a simple story in the "got to collect them all" style.  Basic rating - 6/10

First thing is first - game is short, simple, and not particularly deep. In many ways, it feels like a first attempt by a single author (which, to be fair, I believe it is). The story is charming, but the initial twist is telegraphed in the first 10 minutes. The second twist is nearly as obvious, if more delayed. However, the story is heartfelt, and the mechanic of revealing additional plot through item collection isn't bad. 

The graphics are fair, if a little boxy - think late N64 or early ps2 grade. 
Music is reasonable.
The combat is simplistic, melee and dash attacks, and the mix of the two is rarely needed, or useful. I beat the game using melee 90% of the time.

Each stage is very individualized mechanically (though the visuals are fairly uniform), which improved the general fun nicely. For example, level 5 is an obstacle course of traps, while 3 involves using various wind currents, and 4 involved light emitters. The challenge ramps up smoothly. However, the overall challenge wasn't too high - I failed to find 2 statues on my first playthrough of the level the entire playthrough, and one was due to me picking an irreversible path. 

I don't think the game has much replay value once everything has been found - and, again, finding everything is fairly easy.

Honestly, this is one of those games that I would naturally give a neutral rating, if I could. It is fun, and worth the hour or two it will take to win it completely, with a nice heart warming conclusion, but it is just too short

43668177.review: At first, I thought the game was cute but ended up being quite meh with nothing really special about it. =/

43433624.review:
Cute in both style and concept, Forward to the Sky harkons back to the PS2 with its nostalgic art style. It falls short in nearly every category, unfortunately. It feels like an early demo of a platformer. 

There's a lot of promise here, but it's simply not polished enough. The puzzles are unique in each level, and setting intention for collecting (in this case, crystals to unlock story) is always a positive. The art style is adorable, and was obviously influenced by just about every PS2 era anime-esque game out there. The controls are rough, clunky and not responsive enough for a platformer that requires such careful movements.

The writing is not exactly top tier. I don't expect Pulitzer-level stuff, but I would hope for some thoughts a little more coherent than "It's beautiful here! (referring to the landscape) --Oh no, I can't go praising a witch!" What does the world's beauty have to do with the witch? It makes no sense. Also, the levels all look identical, save for the different puzzle element swapped out in each stage.

The voice acting is cheesy, and sounds like a bad fan anime dub, but we see that in all kinds of games I like. 

This is the kind of game I really wish we could give neutrals for. It's not really a full fledged game, but there's still something charming about it that kept me going. I knew it was bad, but, in a weird way, I enjoyed myself. Still, I can't recommend it in its current state.

5/10

43015731.review:
A short puzzle platformer that doesn't outstay its welcome. The game is very short (2.5 hours to complete with some glitchiness) I started the game with an xbox controller but ended up switching to mouse and keyboard and found that far more responsive (strange but true). 

I liked the puzzles, they were simply but elegant and never frustrating. Combat is a bit too simple and the game could have skipped it altogether but it won't ruin your day.

There are some collision detection problems (especially on the fifth level) and I had to restart the game to finally finish it but I'm glad I played it to the end.
This brings up one of the aspects of the game that I didn't much like: If you die you start from the beginning of the level. You can die either through losing in combat (controls are a bit wonky and hitboxes vague) or if you lose too much health to the environmental dangers (collision detection can be very off).
This is a strange choice given that the game actually has a good in-level checkpoint system in place. If you fall off a platform you don't die and your balloon rescues you and puts you back not far from where you fell. Why the death mechanic is so much more punitive is anyone's guess. Fortunately the levels aren't too long so you do end up back to where you left off relatively quickly.

I got this in a bundle and felt it was priced appropriately as such. If you got this in similar fashion then I recommend giving it a play. It's cute and short and not particularly frustrating and plays well with keyboard and mouse.

42818588.review:
Disclaimer: I'm not a fan of anime. I've never gotten the attraction.
That said, this is a pretty decent game. There are some good puzzles, the levels aren't too long, and some of the enemies can be difficult but are never overwhelming. The end of the last level before the finale could use some polish though, the beam things seemed inaccurate - there were a few times I should have been shocked but wasn't, and many times I don't know why I was shocked. That part was frustrating and felt like it required as much luck as skill.
My other complaint was the Princess. Is she supposed to be a small child who really shouldn't have a sword, or is it just the anime style that makes her look young? I'm fairly certain it's the latter, in which case she's a complete idiot. As the story unfolded I had my own suspicions, but sometimes it was like she completely ignored it. You want to ask her 'Did you not hear what the crystals just said?'. Maybe that's an anime thing though, I don't know.
The story itself could have been fleshed out a little more (Why was the 'Witch' the way she was?) but it's decent enough. As you collect crystals you learn more, and if you don't collect enough on a level then there'll be a hole because you can continue, but you'll be missing a piece of the story. I'm not sure how I feel about this mechanic. This isn't a game you'd play for the story, but the story does drive the game forward effectively.

Specific gripes:
[list]
[*] Hitboxes are extremely jank and unpolished.
[*] Combat is so simplistic and repetitive you'll grow tired of it after the first 2-3 fights.
[*] Voice acting is 2000's anime fandub levels of bad.
[*] Movement/Combat is basic and lacks any real weight to it.
[*] Very confusing menus.
[/list]
Again, the bottom line is that it feels like a hobby project or an aspiring developer's first "real" game.
There's a game here, but just not a good one. Not because it doesn't work, but just because it's unpolished and uninspired.

42477750.review: A cute and simple game. It is fairly short, taking me a little under two hours to complete the six levels. The goal of each level is to collect one-hundred crystals and make it to your hot air balloon, breaking statues and fighting skeleton monsters in order to do so. Each level brings a new mechanic to work with which sets up puzzles that block your path, and additionally, new variants of skeleton are introduced as well. Once one-hundred crystals are collected for a level, you unlock some more of the story behind the sky tower, of which in completion reads out like a story book. There is not immense depth, because the plot and dialogue does make it feel like you are playing through a children's story book; but, this is not necessarilly a bad thing, it creates a cute and quaint atmosphere which is enjoyable, and often brought me a smile. Overall, I would recommend this game. (Though, it will likely feel more worthwhile if bought while on sale.)

42452479.review:
Sometimes I wonder if I'm playing a different game than the other people who review it.  
Forward to the Sky stands out, in my mind, as a rather bad game. It has floaty controls, bad hit detection and terrible voice acting, yet it sits (at the time of writing) at "Very Positive"

[B]Graphics & Sound[/B]
The graphics in Forward to the Sky is hardly amazing, in fact it looks a bit dated, like something released in the early 00's, but with slightly better lighting and a higher resolution. Textures are flat and repetitive, and the models look like they have a low polygon count. Of course, the technical aspect is not everything, a game can be built on ancient tech, and yet look good due to a strong art direction. In my mind the art direction in forward to the sky is acceptable, and while I do appreciate the use of more vibrant colours, the rest is just "meh". Not terrible, but not good either.  

Sound effects are alright. Not something you think of, but they could have been worse. They serve their purpose. But the voice acting, oh the voice acting. It seems like they just decided to let some intern do one take, and then used that, because this is some of the most uninspired voice acting I've ever heard. It's not funny bad, it's just uninspired, flat and boring.  
  
[B]Gameplay[/B]
The gameplay in Forward to the Sky is marred by issues. Combat with enemies is simplistic and quite boring, as there seems to be very little strategy involved. At least early in the game. It reminded me of Fable 3, only even less involving, and Fable 3 had amazingly simplistic combat. 
Platforming is hampered by really floaty controls. It feels like gravity is not quite what it should be, and the character moves through the air in an odd way. What I'm getting at is that platforming is not well made, and there's a bit of it.
Then we have the hit detection. I quickly started to suspect that the hit boxes of objects did not match the models very well, and tested on some spiked, and as suspected, I would get hit even when the model was not touching the spikes. It's as if the hitboxes are too big compared to the models. 
These issues all add up to a game that feels amateurish at best, and is really not fun to play.  
 
[B]Closing thoughts[/B]
What more is there to say about this game? It's bad. It works, but it's simply a bad game. And as a cherry on top of all the other issues, the main menu puts style over usability. It's not a massive issue, and if the rest of the game was good, I would have easily been able to forgive the poor main menu, but when there are so many other issues, it just becomes another annoyance. Had this been a student project, it would have been acceptable, but as commercial software, it's not worth your time and money.

42323177.review:
This is one of those games that makes you wish there was a more neutral option, but if I'm forced to choose between being positive or negative overall I guess I'll have to lean to positive. The game surely has its flaws, but I did enjoy it for the most part.

The elements that interested me the most were the puzzle platform aspects. Each of the six stages present a new concept to tackle, and while each one doesn't appear past its debut stage it does mean players get to take on a variety of tasks such as rolling rocks to reach high up ledges or activating crystals to alter the presence of platforms and walls. Hunting down the crystals needed to fully reveal the story was also fun, with at least one crystal statue per stage being in a place that's visible when looking around as you explore but requiring some careful thought to actually reach. In general the trek from the beginning to the exit was fun, requiring players to look around and explore to find the next path onwards and upwards.

That said, platforming itself can be a little tricky because the controls are rather slippery. The Princess appears to have two movement speeds - not moving and full pelt with nothing inbetween. Most of the time it's not too big an issue, especially as falling into the abyss has no actual downside other than the game resetting you close to where you fell, but it can still be annoying when trying to navigate some of the small platform segments and accidentally shooting off the edge trying to reposition yourself. Likewise aerial movement can feel weird which can make directing her to the right spot a little tricky.

The final boss fight was pretty fun, with multiple stages and some neat ideas like using its own attacks against it or carefully circling around to attack while it's locked in an attack animation. Sadly this fight really is the only notable highlight of combat. The actual mechanics involved are a bit sloppy which can result in many encounters only being serviceable, outside of the final boss and a few of the large mobs that require good movement around. Some encounters are quite irritating though, like the sword and shield enemies where their walking and shield bashing animations look identical or the wizard that spams massive ice spikes all around it.

At 1.7 hours it was a pretty short game, but enjoyable enough to be worth it.

A witch who is only trying to spend some time alone with her crystals is interrupted when an annoying princess barges into her tower.

You run around hitting skeletons, solving (simple) environmental puzzles and collecting crystals.

The controls feel sluggish, the fighting is not very well done (I just used the basic attack to kill everything), and you have so much health that you don't really need to bother dodging any enemy attacks.

The whole thing (including finding all collectibles) can be done in two hours.

As you can probably tell I have way more negative than positive things to say about this game, and I was planning to give it a negative review. [i]However[/i], I did end up finishing the game in pretty much one sitting, and despite its flaws it wasn't [i]that[/i] bad, so I ended up giving it a positive (=neutral) review.

If you keep your expectations low, and get the game while it's on sale, you probably won't be [i]too[/i] disappointed.

42186192.review:
Played With: Keyboard and Mouse, Windows 10

[h1] Pro: [/h1]
Simple but Cute: The art style is very simple and could very well be mistaken for an early PlayStation 2 game but I think it works to its advantage as it differentiates itself from the crowd. 

Pleasent Soundtrack: The music that's composed for the game is nice and upbeat and matches really well with the visuals. 

[h1]Neutral:[/h1]
Trying to be a Puzzle Platformer: The game has a decent grasp of the puzzle platforming and has many systems implemented that spice up the game scattered throughout each level. However, the mechanics aren't used to their full potential giving the player the bare minimum puzzles that can be seen in any other puzzle platformer, which is a shame. This isn't helped by the lack of shadow which makes landings hard to predict. 

Story and Voice Acting: There is an effort here however it's not great. The story is so simple that you'll most likely figure it out after the first level is completed, however, if you don't the characters will make sure you do as the princess (she has no other name) will exposit to you each level about her shifting opinion on the witch (also has no name). 

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
Terrible Optimization and Buggy Hitboxes: For such a simple game it stutters without a pause, making the platforming a nightmare at times. Meanwhile avoiding spikes and other environmental obstacles can be an issue as they will hit you even if you're not standing on them.  

Combat: The combat is a chore and totally optional, defeating enemies will give you crystals which just unlock the story bits at the end of each level. I'd suggest just skipping the fights up until the last level where you have to fight a boss of the game.  

[h1]General Thoughts:[/h1]
For an hour's worth of time, it's not a bad, but it feels much more like a demo than a real game. It's unpolished, it feels like there could be a good game here the style and music are good and the puzzle platforming can be charming. Nevertheless, the gameplay is either very shallow or just broken and it along with optimization need serious work.

41987230.review:
[b]Forward to the Sky[/b] is a medium-short third-person action adventure game whom the player takes the role of a Princess. This Princess, has a very distinct mission; To defeat the evil witch and gain recognition and applauses!

Accordingly to the legend, an evil witch lives on the top of the tower, surrounded by her evil minions who follow her villainous deeds. The tower was once the peaceful home for its inhabitants, who worked on the mines, extracting crystals to sustain their humble lives, until that flagitious day, where a baby girl was born with the ability to form crystals within her body.

The young girl grew apart from everybody, and the miners progressively noticed the low and unprosperous mining results, and everyone eventually blamed the girl as the culprit. Legend has it, the young girl attacked the mine workers with the crystals themselves, and became the ultimate fearful witch! The Princess must now rid the world of such meanie witch and return the crystals to its people.

Developed by [i]Animu Game[/i], a small team dedicated to Anime-based games, [b]Forward to the Sky[/b] was their very first game published on Steam back in 2015, 3 years ago to be precise, and up to this day, the feedback has been positive among Steam users. Although the game is short, the objective was simple; to create something interesting, fun and compelling. Mission accomplished!

The player controls the Princess, in her journey through the Tower in a mixture of action and platforming. Against the evil minions, the player can use just two different attacks, and with them, two different combos respectively. However, to climb up this tower, simple attacks won’t be enough, as you’ll have to jump through moving platforms, gears, and even giant stone spheres.

Creating platforming elements can be tricky for any studio, and we’ve seen many succeed and fail, but in this case the ending result is very positive, with a easy and fun movement system. Platformers are part of every youth, and this game is highly recommended for young gamers!

[i]Animu Game[/i] presents us a very Anime-Based Princess, whom, although swings a sword bigger than herself, it’s extremely cute, and we surely appreciate the details on her dress, such as her bow ties. She is a princess, after all, and one willing to take matters into her own hands!

The visuals are very appealing to the eyes, and since this adventure is portrayed through different parts of the day, we get to enjoy different weather, going from a beautiful sunny morning, into a magical night, and ending in a wrapped torrid sunrise! Although the levels are repetitive and simple, it has some sufficient details, such as wildflowers and moss, leaving a faint impression you really are in ancient ruins.

The small story-plot is told by folklore and legends in animage/text sequence of short notes, almost like a puppet play. These story segments are unlocked if one collects every crystals in the level, and there are 100 to gather in 6 different levels.
Crystals aren’t easy to gather, as they are very well guarded by evil skeletons! These are the only enemies you’ll encounter, and they have different classes too; warriors, mages, archers and even heavy warriors. The combat is not complex enough to perform huge and extreme combos, so you’ll most likely feel like taking them one by one, if you can get that attention individually that is.
Although simplistic, don’t underestimate this title, as enemies have really good hitboxes and clearly a fantastic reaction to the player. Their group behavior is pretty good as well, so you’ll never have the same fight twice.

Worry not brave Princess, because the skeletons are not what you’ll most fear in this adventure. Crystals are running wild, especially with their laser beams, and that’s definitely tricky. The hitboxes for our main character could have been improved, but not game breaking!Since we are talking about platforming mechanics, you’d expect to fall to your death, but no...
Falling over the leges won’t kill our protagonist, as her truthful air balloon comes to the rescue, but remember though, losing all your life means a new level star over!

PC settings are really basic ones as seen on many other Unity engine games, with just three major options to choose from; Resolution, Fullscreen mode or Windowed, and graphic options, going from Fastest for better performance to Fantastic, where the best visuals are. Among these options, light effects seem to be the heavier one, where my GTX 750 Ti struggled the most.
Input for joystick or controller is also available, but the game is extremely well optimized for keyboard and mouse.

[b]Forward to the Sky[/b] would be fully voiced, if not for the storytelling, as both the Princess and Witch are voiced over in English during their adventure. The audio works are pretty good, and worth any Anime audio-subbed, we’ve been having this last couple of years on TV. That’s not saying much, but this is a small game as well.
Music is included, and it’s free for owners of the game on Steam. The soundtrack can be found on the OST folder in the game files, and although we have nothing but respect for developers and publishers who give their soundtracks for free, I personally got to wonder why releasing the tracks with such low quality as 128kbps of bitrate!

Overall [b]Forward to the Sky[/b] is a fantastic and a pleasant short adventure about a cute Princess who’s determined to defeat an evil Witch, but as in myths and legends, there’s always more than meets the eye.

Came into this knowing it was a short game. Expected that to mean it would be a project by a solo dev/small team with realistic expectations of their abilities and therefore designed a small game they could polish to a high standard. That is not the case.
Everyones mentioned the framrate issues. There's also broken hitboxes, a combat system so barebones that it needn't exist and puzzles that were seemingly untested (timed spikes that you can just jump over on the first level for example,or lasers to jump over on the fifth that dont extend to the full platform allowing you to just walk around them).
The game is not entirely bad (a lot of Souls fans will appreciate the intricate level geography). But a cute character with a comically large sword doesn't fix the fundamental problems of 'being a game' that this product has. So, a rare downvote from me I'm afraid.
