41106500.review:
I bought this whilst it was on offer purley because it gave off the nostalgia vibe of an old PS1 platformer. The controls are simple, the story is short and sweet and the level design is actually really well done and intuitive. 

Puzzles are simple and have limited combinations making them easy to pick up and uderstand where you went wrong. The game has you collect gems in each level which, with a keen eye, can easily be done in a single playthrough. There is no lives system, anytime you make a mistake and fall off you are simply ported back to where you last were. Instead you have a health bar that depletes as you take damage but there are no health items to replenish it so you cant just brute force the larger packs of mobs, however it is large enough to not have to worry about it most of the time.

The only gripe i would have, and it is a really basic one, is that a lot of the sceanery is destructable but doent serve a purpose other then in one or 2 specific parts. Due to this I assumed that there would be items hidden inside the sceanery and speant a lot more time on level one then i should have.

Although the game is short with only 6 levels  I would highly recommend this as a beginers game for kids so that they can be introduced to the old puzzle solving problems and item collection that made great PS1 generation platformers. If your also looking for a quick and fun nostalgia trip then this is the game for you.

40967524.review:
Pros:

-Level design: The difficulty of puzzles is somehow between 'boring and passed without any second of thought' and 'frustrating and had to look for walkthrough', which is actually nice. Every stages have also a different puzzle mechanics.

-Enemies variety: Kinds of enemies are pretty much for a game of 2 hours. The boss battle in final stage is a little bit too easy but the fight is still fun and quite spectacular.

-Soundtrack: The BGMs are not really ear-catching, but again pretty much for a game of 2 hours. Every stages of like 20 mins have a different BGM, keeping you refreshed.

-Character and artwork: Not really outstanding, however still comfortable to see.

Cons:

-Plot: I wondered should I call it plot, as the story is even worse than Disney Princesses.

-Length: It just takes me 2 hours to finish all puzzles and achievements. It has also none replay value.

-Control: The control in character, objects and combats are all pain in the a*s. The controller supports outside actual gameplay are even more confusing. The UI seems to be designed for keyboard and mouse alone.

-Showcase-like gameplay: While new puzzle systems are adopted in every new stages, those in last stages are completely discarded. Deepening of game mechanics is particularly important for puzzles yet hardly observed in this game. The single-use systems make the game really short.


Overall comment:
Definitely a meh for the gameplay. If you would like to support independent developer, go for it. If you are coming for a good game, you might need to think twice.

40570440.review:
This game oddly enough reminds me of Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time in that it has fun puzzle sections interrupted by annoying combat sections. That is where the similarities end though, this is not in the same league as Prince of Persia.

The puzzles invoke the usual fair of pushing buttons, moving things around and avoiding obstacles. They are pretty straight forward but satisfying. And you don’t get penalised for falling off, which is nice.

The combat is slow and annoying. At first I just charged in waving my sword about and was swiftly killed. You need to pick off the enemies one at a time by getting a few hits in then flipping back out of the way of their attacks. The combat just felt like pointless roadblock before the next fun puzzle as you need to defeat all the enemies to unlock the full story.

Aside from that the game is pretty short; it looks decent enough; the music isn’t bad and the simple story is engaging enough to keep your attention. The game has partial controller support in that the controller does not work on the menu but can be used in the levels themselves. I’d recommend the keyboard and mouse though as it feels much nicer.

So overall this game is not a bad way to kill an hour or two but it is nothing special.

Forward to the Sky es un proyectito Indie muy cuco, que para bien y para mal parece un proyecto de fin de carrera.

Ignoraría la historia, una mera excusa cliché para acompañar a la acción, si no fuera porque está doblada (al inglés) lo cual es sorprendente. No es que sea un trabajo de 10, pero es un detalle curioso.

Los gráficos son resultones pero nada espectaculares. La princesa y el escenario (solo cambia el fondo entre los seis niveles) tienen un regusto anime muy aceptable. La bruja, no tanto. Los enemigos creo que son assets comprados, pero tampoco afecta en nada. 

La música cumple sin ser asombrosa, aunque hay una de ellas que es claramente peor que el resto. Te estoy mirando a tí, nivel 3...

El principal problema es que aunque tiene su encanto, hay muchos detalles por pulir: El control es muy básico, las animaciones de la princesa son bruscas , faltan algunos efectos gráficos y de sonido...
Nada es terriblemente grave, pero empañan una propuesta inocentona y simpática que podía haber sido mucho más recomendable.

Si te apetece un plataformas sencillito y no muy largo (yo me lo he ventilado en una hora y media yendo medio rápido) y lo encontráis de oferta, es un divertimento aceptable con una interesante variedad de puzzles.

38322091.review:
A very cutesy 3D puzzle platformer with some barebones hack and slash combat. The game is rather short and can be beaten in an afternoon, and while I don't think it gives a lasting impression it had a nice story and some interesting puzzles.

It didn't hold any real challenge for me outside of some of the later puzzles and the combat felt a little wonky and repetitive, however that also makes it easy to pick up and play and more accessable to casual players. Due to the cute art direction, the story that could have been taken straight out of a fairy-tail and the very child-like voice acting, I believe this game could be very appealing to younger audiences.

I recommend this game to anyone looking for a gift for a younger family member, perhaps as something a parent could play with their child and help them with some of the more difficult puzzles. It does have some minor cartoon violence but delivers a good message and I think it could be good for improving problem-solving skills. Outside of that though, I'd say pick this up only if you're looking for a short puzzle game with a cute asthetic.

37847275.review:
Forward to the Sky is a very short (~1 hour) fairytale platformer with a very low difficulty level and moderate replayability.  The game consists of 6 levels in which the player is supposed to collect 100 crystals by destroying statues (3 per level), and defeating the skeletal minions that populate the sky tower.  The skeletons are pretty easy, and two of the statues on each level are easily found as you progress, but on each level there is one statue that is trickier to reach.

A good choice for kids or those that are young at heart.

Gameplay - 9/10 (Little commands yet so many things to do, its great that I needed to be imaginative.)

This first game release on Steam by Animu Game is a 3D action game with hack and slash, platforming, puzzle solving and hunting collectibles. It features an unnamed Princess who decide to explore the ruins of a sky tower and investigate the origins of the sky tower and an unnamed Witch across 6 levels.

31164769.review:
Empecemos por decir que es del tipo rompecabezas, con mucho de plataformero y una ligera sazón de RPG de acción en tercera persona. La historia es bastante simple y corta como el juego mismo, por lo que resulta genial para aquellos que gustan de los juegos cortos y sin mucho trasfondo. Al principio no me gustó por la rapidez con la que se mueve la cámara (que se puede modificar en las opciones y que recomiendo sea disminuida al mínimo), pero una vez dominada la jugabilidad, se hace un viaje cortito, como a la tienda. El personaje es una princesa que debe aventurarse a una torre en el cielo para derrotar a una malvada bruja, allí, conforme vaya superando los niveles, se enterará de la historia que rodea a la torre y la bruja.

👸¿Te gustan los juegos cortos? Este es para ti. ¿Te gustan MUY cortos? Doblemente para ti. Lo completé, con todo y logros de Steam, en un aproximado de dos horas.
👸Tiene cromos y logros en Steam. Ambos son pocos como el juego mismo.
👸No ocupa mucho espacio en la computadora.
👸Los gráficos son coloridos, decentes y muy "kawaii sugoi desu ne!!" si estás en ese tipo de cosas. Son gráficos 3D.
👸El juego se salva solo cada vez que terminas un nivel.
👸Jugabilidad con teclado y ratón.
👸Voces en inglés, subtítulos en español.
👸¿Te caíste de la torre? No hay problema, no te quitan vida por ello.
👸Los puntos de vida se resetean cada vez que comienzas un nuevo nivel, así que no importa que el anterior lo terminases casi muriendo.
👸La banda sonora va de regalo con el juego.
👸Si eres feminista, apúntate, no vi un solo hombre de principio a fin.

☠ Debido a que los niveles son tan cortos, no hay salvado manual dentro de cada uno, por lo que tendrás que pasar cada uno de un tirón.
☠ Si te gustan los juegos de rompecabezas difíciles, este no es el juego para ti.
☠ Las peleas con los enemigos son bastante sencillas y les agarras el truco casi de inmediato. No hay gran variedad de enemigos, un solo tipo (esqueletos) de diferentes clases.
☠ La batalla final... no es difícil, pero sí algo fastidiosa.
☠ La banda sonora... creo que no le presté mucha atención, si soy honesto. No sobresale.
☠ Las opciones pueden confundirte la primera vez que abras el juego puesto que tendrás que guiarte por los iconos, ya que no traen texto. 
☠ Si piedes mucha vida, cuidado, no hay cómo recuperarla, salvo cuando inicies de nuevo o pases a un nuevo nivel.
☠ La cámara se mueve excesivamente rápido (la controlas con el ratón), disminuye su velocidad antes de ponerte a jugar.

No esperes mucho de este juego, mas este comentario no es para minusvalorarlo, sino para que no te hagas una idea errónea sobre él. Cumple lo que promete y ya. Es atractivo, corto y relativamente barato, aunque más cuando está de oferta.

"Forward to the Sky" is an overall nice game, albeit really short without much development. The game is pretty simple: walk, move, attack, reach the goal. A lovely cute charming game with a fairy tale feeling.

You play as a cute Princess trying to reach the top of the Sky Tower to defeat the witch and being praised by everyone.
With your trusty sword you slay skeletons and with your wits you will solve puzzles to advance.
And if you find all the crystals you will reveal the true story of the wich and the tower. But for that you will need to defeat all enemies and find all three statues in each chapter!

So, is a cute little short charming game with tons of fun!

Cute short little 3D action platformer.
Only 1-2 hours of gameplay and easily 100%-able.

The movement, camera, and attack mechanics are all on point, though enemy variety is pretty bland and the character has no jumping or special attacks.

You can backdash cancel out of any attack, adding some depth, but the character has so much health and the enemies are so dim-witted that none of that is required in the slightest.

Controlling the Princess is a wonderful experience.  Everything is snappy and she goes exactly where you want, with very little lag on her attacks.

If the game were longer and more fleshed out, this could easily be a great title.

29686490.review:
First-Hour Impressions:

Menus:
System menues are cryptic and (sometimes) buggy. Had to exit game once because settings menu caused permanent grey overlay, disabling any further input.

Controls:
-Game lacks deadzone for analog stick and character movement is stuck in 8-direction.
-Menu navigation with controller is difficult and non-intuitive.
   In short, game was developed more for keyboard/mouse than controllers.
-If you don't jump, character falls like a lead weight instead of accelerating downward.
-Mouse isn't bound to the window of the game (even in fullscreen). This can lead to clicking outside the window instead of attacking.
-Can teleport onto top of platform if jumping high enough next to it.

-Attacking needs polish: Button clicks are queued such that if you double click, your character will attack twice. However, if the second click is done toward the end of the previous strike, the second strike won't happen until the next time you click to attack, upon which the character will attack twice despite clicking only once the second time. This can make your character fall off the sides of the map if you're unlucky.

-Holding down backflip button will cause character to continually backflip rather than backflipping once.
   Can be an issue since character backflips rather far and may lead to accidentally falling off the map.
   Additionally, since shift button is backflip, the character backflips when opening/closing steam overlay menu. Combine these two issues and you'll find yourself backflipping off of the map quite often.

Presentation:
-Graphics are pleasantly cel-shaded.
-Levels are geometrically simple and easily navigable.
-Puzzles and platforming!
-Voice acting isn't great but isn't terrible.
-Dialogue tends to interrupt or overlap itself.
-Falling off the map simply brings you to the general area you were in, so only seconds of play need to be redone.
-Losing all your health makes you redo the entire level over. This wouldn't be as much of an issue if the battle controls were better.

The game looks nice so far though it could use some polish.

29598735.review:
Forward to the Sky is short action-platformer that I'm not entirely sure how I picked up.

You guide your generic moeblob through six levels of generic platforming challenges, and throw out your two combos (press one button five times or press the other button four) against the four generic enemy types - Skeleton Mage, Skeleton Archer, Skeleton Warrior, and Mr. Bones.

So this is fine, so far. It has the good sense to be short in the face of not having any depth, and there's always room for games that don't waste your time but do what they do well.

The trouble is that it's not any good. 

[h1]"Yes, I will win the adoration of others!"[/h1]
[i]- Yeah that sounds exactly how you think it does[/i]

The environments and characters themselves are fine, the cell-shaded look certainly pays off despite the lack of asset variety. The OST fits, the designs are okay (even if the enemies are a bit F2P mobile game-ish), the lighting actually works, the problems don't start there. They start with the mechanics.

Movement is mapped to eight cardinal directions that operate independantly of the camera. This means that you can be right next to an enemy and still miss with the lunge combo. And often will.

A fair few of those enemy types get larger versions that ignore hitstun and are otherwise unstaggerable. This is combined with the Skeleton Warrior having a few attacks with no startup or telegraphing. Or the Mage stunlocking you with its wonky hitboxes. Or the Archer constantly running away. So double the unfun to fight. 

Mr. Bones is alright though.

Most of the platforming challenges are trite timing or physics puzzles, and combined with the locked movement directions they're not much fun either. 

None of these remotely break the game. You've always got plenty of time of correct your falls (along with falling just meaning a return to the last checkpoint) and more than enough health to sleep your way through levels. It's just annoying. The whole game is just short and annoying, without even mentioning the characters.

[h1]"Gah... wah... geurgh"[/h1]
[i]- The two characters cry constantly and I don't like them.[/i]

The two lead characters repeat themselves more often than a broken record, cry at the drop of a hat, and sound like 30 year olds sucking on helium. 

Plot is that bullied moeblob cries a lot until spunky young moeblob comes along and repeats how much she wants to banish the bullied moeblob. Then it turns out that it was all a big misunderstanding and then they shag or something I don't care.

Forward to the Sky is pet peeve of a game. It is a short, annoying roadbump in your existence.

It demands little and delivers nothing. Don't even bother.

26742826.review:
In [i]Forward to the Sky[/i], the player takes control of a courageous not-Saber-Lily princess character with an oversized sword (which I'm guessing is not-Excalibur or something she was gifted by Cloud Strife) on a rescue quest through an old, worn, gigantic tower of stone, algae, and crystals floating amongst the clouds to find and defeat a legendary witch (not-Miyu) in order to rescue the tower's supposed population.
It's very cute and has a nice soundtrack, plus very simple gameplay within a lovely environment.
Definitely can be fun if one is very bored and got it on sale, lol.
It is very easy to get into, could be a pleasant deviation from whatever is the norm for the buyer.

This game is tagged "action" and "adventure", I would say it is specifically a simple dish of hack 'n slash with platforming and a little side of puzzle-solving.  I think only inexperienced gamers may have some difficulty with the game.
It is very short, easily completed in under an hour, two or more if you go for all the achievements and obtaining every last crystal.

I've got a long list of complaints, but I won't delve into that.  "A game everyone are able to finish..." I think that's a poor excuse for what feels like a dreadfully half-finished game.

I had a little bit of fun in the end despite its brevity and faults, so I don't want to down vote this title.  I'll reiterate: it is an okay choice for the bored that like platforming, hack 'n slash, and a pretty soundtrack that envelops some bright and pretty artstyle.  This is a casual game to be enjoyed while kicking back and taking it very, very easy.

I did like seeing what the developer tried to do with this game, if they make a vastly improved and more elaborate sequel, I'd totally be up for that.

A simple game with simple mechanics and a simple story.

It's just a cute straight forward puzzel platformer that 
has a bit of cringe worthy story and voice acting.

But why am I recommending it?

During my first 30 seconds of the game my initial reaction
was that I wouldn't recommend it. But after 5 minutes of playing
I was drawn into the carefree atmosphere of the game
and found myself similing from the entire 1.5 hour experience.

That's when I realized that in this era or DarkSouls, FF, WItcher
and all those every other "serious and hardcore" games
that will suck 10s if not hundreds of hours, Forward to the Sky 
has offered me a laid back and relaxing game. One with 
no grinding, no secrets to find, no boss to plan several hours to defeat.

It's just something that reminded me (and I hope anyone who 
decides to play the game) of what games should be.

25873740.review:
I found this game rather enjoyable given I bought it on sale.  Definitely feels like a "my first game" attempt, but it's rather enjoyable.  If you're bored, this might be a solution for the afternoon.

Pros: 
-Bought it on sale and got some enjoyment out of it (if I had fun, that's a good thing)
-Cutesy feel to the main character
-Not too difficult to figure out the puzzles when they load properly.  This seems like more a story-centric game which benefits from that kind of thing.

Cons:
-DO NOT USE WITH ANALOGUE STICK!  Seriously -- your character moves at the same speed regardless of how far you move the analogue stick.  There are no precise movements.  
-Camera controls are a little fussy.
-100% in only 3 hours (although for the price that's not a big deal)
-one of the puzzles was missing a piece when it first loaded (restarting the game fixed that)
-Framerate isn't as good as it could be -- in fact, if I stood in place and rotated the camera around you could see it go from smooth motion looking at the sky to ~15-30FPS looking towards the main part of the map.  Some occasional graphical artifacts when looking at walls from a distance.  This seemed to be regardless of the graphics settings and resolution.

My system specs:
-Phenom II X4 965 BE at stock speed
-4GB of DDR2-1066
-NVidia GTX 750TI OC (2GB video memory)
-Arch Linux with Kernel version 4.7.2 (64-bit)

25850336.review:
If you've played lesser-known 3D puzzle platformers back in the late 90's and early 2000's, you'll feel right at home with Forward to the Sky. The game doesn't do anything new or fancy. It isn't nearly as polished as Super Mario or Crash Bandicoot, but I had fun in the 2.9 hours it took me to 100% this game. It felt like I was a 10 year old again playing a random game like Kao the Kangaroo or Super Magnetic Neo on an old Dreamcast Magazine Demo Disc (remember those?).

I wouldn't necessarily pay full price for this title as it is very short and to the point, but on a Steam sale, I say it is definitely worth it if you're a fan of nostalgia. I got it on sale and I had a great time. People say the voice acting is horrible, but it sounds like any mid-budget anime dub I've ever heard before. Completely passable. 

tl;dr - Get it on sale if you're a fan of 3D Puzzle Platformers from a time where devs were still trying to figure out how to bring platformers to the 3D realm.

25793861.review:
To be FAIR.

I DO NOT RECOMMEND THIS GAME.

Not the full price at least.

I got all achievement [u]under 2 hours[/u], including run into [i]a bug that require me to restart whole level[/i].

But I think it's ok to try this [b]ON SALE[/b].


[h1]Art-style/Music[/h1]
The music is fine, not rememberable.
The art-style are cute.
Both of them could have more polishing, for a indie they are good enough.

[h1]Control[/h1]
Not good. It's bearable, but not good.
For basic controls they were ok. In combat they're bad.

[h1]Storyline[/h1]
It's fine. Typical short adventure.
I just hope they would be more after the main game.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Forward to the Sky is focusing on puzzle element more than action.

Even the protagonist wear a huge sword, the combat is just...there.
There're different enemy types require strategy, in a manner of speaking.
Some of them just have more hp and ignore your attacks so it's kinda harder to beat them down.

In short, combat are boring.

But the final boss is GREAT.
If they put more effort into it, it would be awesome.

For the puzzle. I think it's fine.
Especially good when you want to get every single crystal.


That's it.
Forward to the Sky is a alright indie game.

"Forward to the Sky" is an adorable puzzle/platformer. As a princess, you try to unlock the mystery behind a witch and her odd relationship with crystals that aren't your standard gems. Although not particularly difficult, some of the puzzles can be a little bit challenging. Each of the areas are relatively small, and everything is simple logic and platforming. The music is very light and appropriate to the game style, and the art direction is simple yet elegant in its own way. The story is not much, but it does keep you wondering. Voice acting is ... there. It's not incredible, but it's by no means bad.

I finished the game to 100% completion (all achievements) in about 2 1/2 hours, but that's with a lot of pauses while I had to take care of something else. If you don't go for all achievements you can probably have it done in less than an hour. It's a good way to play in short bursts, such as one or two levels at a time, but it's also short enough that it doesn't feel padded.

Overall, it's a simple yet very enjoyable way to spend an hour or two.

23914571.review: Forward to the Sky puts you in the control of a petite, unnamed princess with a huge sword on a quest to ascend a tower and vanquish an evil witch; what is a typical fairy tale framework ends up being used as a springboard to deliver a basic, if heartwarming twist where the only evil is the folly of fear and distrust on both sides of the conflict. While it's simple, short and certainly has its rough edges (though it accounts for it with a rather forgiving gameplay structure), Forward to the Sky is a sweet and adorable game.

23842664.review:
Forward to the Sky...to summarize, it's a bit of a platformer, with some puzzle and action elements. There's a modicum of backstory, but even without 100% completion (which is required to get all the details), you can probably fill in the gist of it yourself. Which doesn't speak too highly about it, but anyways...

The combat in this game is, shall we say, subpar. There're only two possible attack moves (which I can't figure out the difference between, practically speaking), and a seemingly useless dodge mechanic. Enemies are either worthless or insanely annoying, and with no way to recover health, the game becomes a bit of an endurance test - can you make it to the end of the level before you run out of health? Not the most compelling gameplay.

The saving grace of this game - and the only reason you should consider looking at it - are the puzzles. Each level introduces an interesting mechanic for you to learn and use, and with only one personal exception, the puzzles have always seemed to be of appropriate difficulty - giving you the satisfaction of solving a problem without much frustration. It would've been nice to see levels combine these mechanics, but considering the other issues with the game, its short length is probably a boon rather than a liability.

For its normal asking cost, I wouldn't, but if you find it on sale and want to spend a couple of hours on some nice puzzles, then why not?

22666916.review:
Waoo! A cute and clever platformer with very nice art style, fresh ideas in every level and only a few hiccups here and there. 

This game is full of ideas and each level has something new to offer. New monsters, puzzle types, ways of moving around... it really makes you think this had to be developed with love. There's no such thing as repetition and lazy level design here.

The combat isn't the biggest part, yet it's done pretty well too. You have two attack types with advanced combo moves, there are walls and pillars that you can use for cover or you can smash them apart and hit enemies on the other side with falling chunks of rock. 

Main downside is the length of the game, especially since it makes you want to play some more. Other problems are rather typical for smaller games - like sometimes a bit unpredictable collision detection, few unimportant graphical glitches and rather oversensitive controls for my taste, especially mid-air.

Tl;dr: You will probably finish this game in a single run, but it will be a very enjoyable one if you like the genre.

22414422.review:
Your player character is adorable, and that's why I bought this game, but sadly that's where the good things end :\

As soon as I loaded the game up I wondered if there was a bug with drawing text on the screen, but no, the menu system really just is a clunky icon-only thing that's a game in itself of figuring out what does what. Kinda like those wordless instructions that come with all sorts of things these days so they don't have to bother to translate it into a hundred different languages.

But that's just the menus, surely the gameplay is ok, right? No, not really. Moving and attacking are mutually exclusive, you can't interrupt your attacks to dodge and you can't attack while in the air, which makes combat frustrating. It isn't very clear what counts as an enemy attack either. There's also no sense of "flow" between one bit of the level and the next - there's a bunch of typical platformer segments in there, moving spike puzzles, moving platforms, lever puzzles, box-pushing puzzles oh and bits of combat - but it's like they were put in willy-nilly rather than creating any sense of progression or building on earlier elements.

Oh, and when you run out of HP? There's no game over animation or anything to tell you you died, you just go to one of those wordless menus that looks more like a pause screen than a game over screen.

All in all the whole game feels like a 3D version of what a bored 14 year old might make in Game Maker. It's just not fun to play.

21683437.review:
[i]Since this won't be the only review you read I'll simply break this review down into a list of pros and cons and then I'll explain why I feel that this game isn't worth recommending.[/i]

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]The game has a nice art style and is pleasnt to look at.[/b]
[*][b]The puzzles aren't too bad although they're nothing too spectacular in the way of puzzles[/b]
[*][b]If you aren't too concerned with stories the one here is short and sweet albeit very predictable[/b]

[i]There's honestly no other positives unless you include the music which is "ok" but it get's repetative rather quickly[/i]
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
[*][b]Optimization is lacking and lags on the latter levels[/b]
[*][b]The platforming isn't fun, it lacks any kind of features that would make it fun there's no sprinting or double jump and you can't even change how high you jump based on how long you hold the jump key down[/b]
[*][b]Put simply the combat is awful it's far too basic, it lacks challenge and feels awful to play[/b]
[*][b]Controller support is shite[/b]

[i]You could say the games too short although the game would be worse if it was longer as you would have to spend more time with the bad platforming and horrible combat[/i]
[/list]

[h1]So why is it not worth recommending[/h1]
What is comes down to is that this game isn't fun to play. On your first playthrough you may find your self enjoying the game somewhat but if you were to step back for a second to take a more objective look at the game you would see that it's rather bad.

The combat in Forward to the Sky could be completly thrown away and nothing would be lost expect for a couple of sales because they wouldn't be able to feature it in promotional images and videos. It's awful, pointless and adds nothing to the experience other then frustration at how little range and "AOE" you have in your attacks.

The platforming is trash and only has one mechanic to it... the jump key and movement keys... you get no double jump, sprinting varying height nothing. You can jump and move that's it for a platformer these mechanics are far too simplistic.

The puzzles are ok however with that said this isn't a puzzle game it's a 3D collectathon puzzle platformer with combat elements. The collectathon part of this game is pointless and is only there to make sure that you kill all enemies and solve the "optional" puzzles. Honestly though if you skipped the collectathon part of this game you could probably beat this in under 30 minutes.

[b]In conclusion[/b]
Forward to the Sky feels like a foundation for a better game as it has ok ideas it's just that they're executed poorly. If the developers were to take these mechanics and improve on them in a new game I wouldn't complain even if it was of the same length because that's the thing I prefer quality to length but with Forward to the Sky you don't get quality or length.

So do I recommend Forward to the Sky?... No, it's not bad but it's not good even if it were free I wouldn't recommend it as the mechanics aren't good but I've said that several times.

[i]I also did a video review if you want to watch that but I doubt you would want to https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1tG_W3szkDc[/i]

[h1]A message to the Devs[/h1]
You're game isn't awful but you need to expand upon and improve the mechanics you have because when your being out matched by old PS2 games your not in a good position.

I can understand it was made by a really little team, but it doesn't excuse the major lack of content the game suffer. Sometime some puzzles elements are only passed through once and than gone with them.

An action-puzzle-platformer with boring action, average puzzling, and ok platforming. Not worth picking up for any of those categories alone, but hey the anime aesthetic is here if that's what you're into. (You can even look at her panties, if you're into that kind of thing)

Some of the later puzzles are actually quite clever (meaning, they take a bit of thinking but aren't frustratingly difficult), and the puzzle mechanics are kinda fun, like rolling around on top of giant boulders. However, the game is designed poorly to the point that performing the right solution to puzzles can feel like you're playing the game wrong. It feels like it shouldn't work and you've found a way to cheat the game.

Controls are annoying to use, especially in battle, and the script and voice acting is downright hilarious.

On the plus side, the devs are very responsive and will try to help with any issues you are having (my camera kept spinning wildly and they gave me advice on fixing it, in the steam forums).

I'm going to click recommend because I enjoyed it, but [b][u] only pick this up (on sale) if you really like platforming games (like me) and/ or anime, and want to scratch that  itch. Not worth it otherwise[/u][/b].

3-4 hours for 100% completion.

21057179.review:
I had a great time playing Forward to the Sky, granted it doesn't last very long (2-3 hours at most), in my opinion it does its job very well.

[b]Pro:[/b]
[list]
[*][i][u]Atmosphere and graphics[/u]:[/i] the atmosphere of this game is gorgeous and immersive. The graphics are very cute and resemble somehow those of an anime.
[*][i][u]Story[/u]:[/i] the story isn't very deep or complicated at all which is why I loved it. There are times when you play games and focus hard on gameplay or story and times, like in the case of Forward to the Sky, where you just want to relax and look at cute things. The story itself is easy to follow and relaxing to listen to.
[*][i][u]Mechanics and gameplay[/u]:[/i] this game is, for the most part, a platformer. Controls are easy to learn and master and don't feel clunky. Some of the levels have also fun mechanics to play with (e.g. the dashing rings or the light puzzles).
[*][i][u]Soundtrack[/u]:[/i] the music in this game is relaxing and yet nostalgic somehow, it's wonderful.
[/list]

[b]Neutral:[/b]
[list]
[*][i][u]Fighting[/u]:[/i] believe it or not, there are fighting parts too in this game. While they don't feel clunky, they are also not too entertaining.
[*][i][u]Difficulty[/u]:[/i] this game is not, by any means, hard. However it makes for an incredible choice for the times you just want to relax.
[/list]

[b]Con:[/b]
[list]
[*][i][u]Length[/u]:[/i] unfortunately this game doesn't last very long, about 2 to 3 hours.
[/list]

[b]Overall:[/b]
Forward to the Sky was a great experience, filled with cute graphics and relaxing atmosphere. It doesn't last long but it's still worth the purchase.
You should absolutely buy it when there's a sale.

[h1]Synopsis:[/h1]
You play as a cute princess with 3 main attacks, dodging traps and figuring out puzzles while trying to regain respect of her people by defeating an evil witch... or so it would seem since you discover some interesting things along the way. 
[h1]Pros:[/h1]
The worlds and game level mechanics become increasingly more beautiful as you progress.

Just one major complaint: it's hard to control the character in a straight line with an analog pad, because movement is not analog (you either move or don't, there's no slow and fast movement) and the deadzone is like 0%. So unless you press forward exactly straight, the character will move diagonally, making platforming more difficult than it should be. In the end I opted for mouse and keyboard and it was very good.

20404044.review:
[h1]Summary:[/h1]
Forward to the Sky is an action adventure where you take role of the loli princess who decides to venture to the sky tower to kill the evil crystal witch. But... something happened there and things may not be as people say. 

This game is a great relaxing platformer, as it is pretty easy overall and anytime you fall down the tower that you're climbing, you'll get back up immediately. I loved that every level, a new gameplay mechanic is brought into the game, so each level has different gameplay. The bad thing is that there are only 5 levels and a bossfight, which you'll beat in about 2 hours, getting 100% achievements meanwhile.

I think the developers could actually squish more out of the game, at least every gameplay mechanic (gravity changes, wind rings, elevators) could get more levels that would just grow in difficulty by the progress. Anyway, the game, even when is short, is entertaining and worth buying - though it's up to you to decide if you'll pay the full price or wait for (another) sale.

[h1]Pros:[/h1]
- [b]Relaxing and entertaining[/b]. Your brain (or fingers) won't melt there, don't prepare to die. You'll just be jumping and slashing with your sword.
- [b]Cute protagonist[/b]. You'll be happy if you are into cute loli princesses.
- [b]Delightful environment[/b] of the sky tower. Also, things around you are destructible! (I might've spent about tenth of my playtime just destroying walls and columns.)
- [b]Voice acting[/b]. Though it's not something coming with extra quality, it was still a nice surprise to hear conversations of princess and witch.
- Controller support.
- Steam achievements.

[h1]Cons:[/h1]
- [b]Short length[/b]. Considering the soundtrack, visuals and the amount of gameplay mechanics, I'd still consider that the price of the game is reasonable.

20140405.review:
This game is awesome. It's a short (~1.5 hours) light-hearted puzzle platformer game.

Every level has its own theme and implements specific gameplay mechanic, which keeps the game fresh until the end. The story is presented both in-game through conversation as you progress through the levels  (they do not interrupt the gameplay) and through short picture/text presentation at the end of each levels.

You can complete each level simply by reaching the balloon at the end but you really should try to get the 100 crystals hidden in every level (25 from monsters, 75 from 3 statues). You're rewarded with additional story bits when you do so.

At first It seemed like this game was too simple and kind of lackluster but as I cleared each level, my opinion changed completely. I just kept going forward compelled to hear more audio interactions between the princess and the witch and to discover and toy with the new mechanics of each level. Overall, the pace turned out to be just right, no mechanic felt overused, every levels brought something new and there was always a surprise around the corner.

I recommend this game!

19898467.review:
This is an excelent, old fashioned puzzler RPG. It's extremely simple and a bit short (got all secrets and achievements on the first try), but lots of fun, definately worth it. It has some well-thought puzzles and a good challenging final boss at the end. The main character is super cute, and the little skeleton monsters are quite charming also. 9/10 Totally recommend.

It is quite atypical for an RPG in that there is no way to restore your health unless you start your current level over. What you start with is all you get for the whole level. But, the controls can be learned quickly enough that you probably won't fall victim to each enemy type's attack more than once. I wish it had better audio quality on the voices, and unlockables like perhaps a bonus level, alternate outfits, higher difficulties, etc. but for that price, I'd say you're getting more than you're paying for.

Besides, everyone, deep down, somewhere in their heart, is a little princess with a big sword searching for crystals through an ancient ruin floating in the sky. You know you are.

19835962.review:
TL;DR Dissappoint: bad mechanics/controls, bad dialouge, bad physics; not even worth the small price it is.

I was so excited from after reading the reviews and watching gameplay but I could not get past the fact that the mechanics of this game were horrible, and there was no proper demo or explanation for anything. At one point there is this random purple shit that knocks you off the platform and the only way to bypass it is to just walk against it and pray. Most of the time, you are left just repeating the same action, as there is literally no other way, until magically the game decides that it will let you get to the next platform. 

Not only that, but the combat is absolute trash. When you have to fight something, it feels like they tried to "spice it up" a bit and just add a lil skeleton dude that you hit once and it dies. 

Oh, and did I mention there is no saving mechanic? On top of having little to no controls or options, the game decides when your checkpoints are. Again, I have no problem with this as most platformers have their own checkpoint system, but this one is unforgiving. I could go so far and even have to sit through an entire dialouge section, and then fall off the cliff and respawn 3 years earlier.
I had such high hopes for this game, but was throughly let down. 

And before anyone says "it's only $8 don't be so harsh", I know and have played plenty of other low-budget indie games, but not putting in at least SOME effort to make it good is unacceptable.

19802270.review:
[h1]Análisis / Review - Forward to the Sky[/h1]

Cuando compras este juego, debes tener claro que no debes esperar grandes cosas de él, el juego ya de por si se muestra bastante sencillo.
Tiene un aspecto visual bastante bonito, que lo hace relativamente atractivo a la vista y te anima a la compra.

[b]Historia:[/b]
La historia es bastante simplona, es bonita y muy corta. Una princesa en busca de la bruja de una antigua leyenda a la que quiere eliminar para convertirse en una heroína local.

[b]Jugabilidad:[/b]
La jugabilidad es muy simple, sin dar lugar a grandes estrategias o pensar demasiado, con un par de combos simples, movimientos toscos y algo abruptos. Al moverte en el juego notas como si el personaje estuviese subiendo escalones todo el tiempo y es por que la cámara no está muy lograda.

[b]Gráficos:[/b]
Los gráficos están bastante desfasados, pero cumplen su papel, ya que al no haber excesivos detalles tampoco se notan en exceso, además la profundidad de los paisajes con partes de torre en el cielo quedan bastante bien y en general cumplen el cometido visual, los que más se benefician en este aspecto son las protagonistas de esta historia, la princesa y la bruja, que son las que más logradas están gráficamente hablando.

[b]Sonido y Música[/b]
Pese a subir al máximo el volumen (in-game), la música a penas se percibe en el juego, siendo bastante suave, sabes que existe, pero no la notas. Algunos sonidos no están muy sincronizados con las acciones que representan y podrían mejorarse. Las voces no están mal, quizá lo más sobresaliente del juego, a parte de su artwork.

[b]Diversión:[/b]
Empiezas a jugarlo esperando un pequeño progreso en el personaje, pero lo único que va sucediendo a lo largo de las fases, son su dificultad para acabarlas, pese a todo el juego no presenta grandes retos, pudiendo terminarlo en un par de horas como mucho (más o menos lo que he tardado yo).
Lo más atractivo es su historia, que aunque sencilla está contada con mucha inocencia y es bonita, pero también esperaba que fuese un poco más extensa.

[b]Extras:[/b]
Estos son prácticamente inexistentes, lo único a modo de extra, están las imágenes de cada capitulo con su inicio y final, solo disponibles, según cuantos capítulos hayas ido completando, como es obvio.

[b]Conclusión:[/b]
El juego sin duda tiene buena base, pero las fases donde se desarrolla están bastante vacías, la historia no es muy profunda y el desarrollo del personaje inexistente, todo podría haberse explotado más.
Diría que el juego está más enfocado a jugadores novatos (niños pequeños) y sin duda para estos, sería un reto mayor.

[h2][url=https://store.steampowered.com/curator/32243713/]Sigue mi Mentor de Steam[/url][/h2]

[b]Mi valoración personal: 5/10[/b]
Es un juego para comprar a bajo precio y entretenido para las 2 horas (aprox.) de duración que está programado.

18330112.review:
Un juego agradable, pero limitado.

Los gráficos están bien (aunque no son la última novedad), la música también, y en general es un buen ARPG.

Los problemas:
- Corto. Te lo puedes pasar en un par de horas.
- Dificultad baja. No voy a discutir excesivamente esto (soy algo torpón y me gusta poder pasarme los juegos que compro), pero gente con más habilidad necesitaría poder poner el juego más difícil.

De lo que sí voy a hablar es de los niveles. Son 6 niveles relativamente cortos (en realidad 5+1). En general, cada nivel tiene un componente de exploración y de puzzle para encontrar las tres estatuas. Luego, cada nivel es temático. El sexto nivel es un caso aparte, ya que es un combate con el jefe.

Esto da la impresión de que podía haber dado mucho más de sí. Cada nivel tiene sus propias reglas, pero no ves puzzles mezclados. Es decir, hay un nivel lleno de rayos de energía y otro lleno de corrientes de aire pero no encuentras un nivel que mezcle puzzles de varios tipos. Por otra parte el encontrar las tres estatuas debería añadir rejugabilidad, pero es bastante fácil encontrarlas.

En resumen: el juego completo parece más bien la demo de un juego. Se hace muy corto, y el diseño de niveles (aunque bastante inteligente) parece más bien el del tutorial de un juego más grande.

Aún así, es un juego que me ha sido muy agradable jugar y lo recomiendo. Preferiblemente si lo encontráis en oferta.

17330114.review:
Forward to the Sky is a cute little puzzle platformer. It follows the story of a Princess who explores the Sky Tower to learn what happened to it and reclaim the crystals. It's a nice, relaxing game with good music and pleasant, vibrant visuals. The game is 6 levels long, and will keep you occupied for about two and a half hours. The combat is very basic with a strong attack, light attack and a dodge, but that's really everything you need. The jumping is good overall but changing direction in mid-air moves Princess a bit further than you'd like to, making precision jumping difficult at times. But the game is forgiving enough that it never really becomes an issue.

The meat of the game is in the puzzle platforming, and it's pretty good at that. Every level introduces new mechanics and presents you with interesting puzzles. None of them are especially taxing though, so don't expect taking hours on finding the solution to a puzzle. The only disappointment was that the game never really put all the different mechanics together to make a truly diabolical puzzle, preferably for the final level.

Overall though, I really enjoyed this game. It's a good, relaxing game with a cute story and mechanics that don't overstay their welcome. People looking for a long or difficult game might want to look elsewhere, but those who want a fun disctraction for a few hours should definitely take a look at this game.

16638518.review:
First, take a second to appreciate that the developer has included a free demo for this game. It's on the store page; no review (not even my stellar, first-rate, excellent, incomparably fantastic review) can match what you'll get from the demo, so if you're on the fence go download it and try it out.

My opinion is that this is a very charming, simple game. I enjoyed the game thoroughly (with a few slight misgivings), and I hope to see more from the developer.

I'll cut right to the chase and tell you that this game is EXTREMELY short. My gameplay stats list it at an hour, but I did play the first few levels without running Steam so it's actually about twice that at 2 hours (I did go back and replay the first 3 levels in Steam to get the achievements, but at that point I remembered the layout and basically just speedran them). There are 6 levels (5 levels, really; the 6th is just a boss fight), so that puts it at right about 20 minutes per level on average. I bought it on sale so I wasn't put off by the lack of playtime, but it is something you should consider.

This game is mostly platforming, with two or three combat setpieces per level between platforming sections. I have absolutely no problem with the platforming beyond the fact that every level introduces a new gimmick, and none of these gimmicks are ever repeated, meaning that the skills you get in one stage never carry on to the next. As an example, the third level introduces wind gust tunnels that you have to navigate to get to different sections of the level, but no other stage has these tunnels. Every stage is mechanically completely different from the next. However, that's really just kind of a nitpick. If the game ever gets a sequel, I'd love to see stages that incorporate the gimmicks from previous stages. Level design does incorporate the gimmicks well, though, and overall each level is pretty fun. Thankfully, the camera is completely controllable and the princess controls great, so there's really no major gripes from me about this portion of the game.

Combat, though, is a little boring and really just amounts to a button masher. You have left-click attacks and right-click attacks, but the difference is minute enough that you can go in swinging either way and it doesn't have an impact on combat. There is also a backflip button, which acts as a dodge, and that's fairly useful late in the game against the mage enemies, but they only appear in the last two platforming stages. Earlier stages can be beaten by literally just tanking every hit and whaling away on the mouse. However, the stages are mostly focused on platforming and like I said there are at max about 3 major "battles" per level, so it's not unbearable.

During each stage you have to pick up the various crystals you find. Small enemies drop one when defeated, big enemies drop three, and statues you break apart are each worth 25 crystals for a total of 100 in each stage. Typically, the split is 25 crystals from enemies and 3 statues. For every 33 crystals you pick up, you unlock one section of that stage's story; if you only collect 33 crystals, for instance, you'll only get 1/3 of that stage's exposition. Honestly, it's kind of a non-issue. If you have absolutely ANY sense of exploration you'll easily find all of the statues (some later stages have statues hidden behind puzzles, but all of them are rather simple, and the statues have a very noticeable glow that is visible even through solid objects) and enemies are NEVER off of the beaten path so it's very rare you'll ever finish a stage without getting all 100 crystals. I don't know what happens if you don't get all crystals from each stage; there might be two different endings depending on whether you get all of them or not, but like I said, it's simple enough to get all of them.

I did have a slight problem with the voice acting. None of it is awful, but none of it is good, either. I would describe it as "endearingly mediocre." The princess and the witch, the two main voices you'll be hearing throughout the game, are both fine, but I really didn't like the third voice actress.

The story is just a setpiece, really. It's there to justify the fact that you're a cute girl jumping around in a tower in the sky. There's nothing wrong with that; the story fills its purpose, and even though it's about the simplest and most cliched story you can think of, it's amusing enough that it doesn't get on your nerves. Though I enjoyed the game and wish it had been longer, I think that if I had had to listen to either the voice acting or the story for much longer it might have started to drag the experience down. As it stands, though, the game is short enough that neither are too grating.

The characters are rendered in a cel-shaded chibi style, which fits the tone and is pretty cute. The early levels are rather plain and bland, but later on there are glowing crystals and colored fogs and other visuals to help keep things interesting. The music is enjoyable and, again, mostly fits the tone of the game.

One thing I WOULD like to complain about is the presentation of the menus. There's no text; everything is done via pictures. This isn't a terrible thing, but I did twice accidentally end the game because I couldn't tell which button was supposed to take me back into the game. I will chalk that up 90% to personal idiocy (just hit the Esc/start button again to get out of the menu, idiot), but even just a single word "Resume" or "Close" would have been helpful. The buttons for camera inversion are also a little awkward. However, this is another tiny nitpick and the game itself is not in any way negatively impacted by this.

Overall, I think this is a thoroughly enjoyable game. Bear in mind the cost when deciding if you want to buy it now or wait for a sale, and above all, since the developer was nice enough to include a demo, play that to see if you want the full product. My guess is that you'll enjoy it.

16351409.review:
´Forward to the Sky` tells the story of a princess that, with the help of her trusty hot air balloon, seeks out to climb an enormous tower high up in the sky, in order to hunt down a witch. On her way, she has to fight her way past  enemies and solve puzzles in order to unlock the passage to the next floor of the tower as well as the "full story", with more lines getting added the more crystals you collect in every stage.

The game is quite charming both in terms of visuals and sound; both add quite a lot to the feeling of being high up an uncountable amount of feets up in the air. However, this doesn´t mean that it´s impressive from a technical point-of-view: It looks very low-res and without much detail, and the only thing that stands out a bit (outside of its style) is the destructibility of the terrain: Most pillars, bricks, stone piles and even some walls can be destroyed with your sword, even possibly hurting you in the process if you aren´t careful. Soundwise, it needs to be said that the voice acting, while not exactly terrible, feels very amateurish as well: While I personally had no problem with it, this may be a downer for others. Controls for the most part are fine, though a bit too floaty and not always as precise as they should be. Combat controls are very simplistic, with two kinds of attack and a parry move; the latter one being kind of useless though (you´re better of just jumping out of the way).

Gameplay-wise, each stage consists of platforming, hitting switches, finding specific statues and defeating enemies, neither of which is particularly difficult even if you aren´t used to platformers in general. Each stage also has one or two unique gimmicks (like boulders that you need to roll on, or lasers that you need to dodge with the right timing) that aren´t reused in other stages, as well as one or two new enemy types. You can´t fall to your death (your trusty hot air balloon will always catch you), but you can die in battle or by getting hit from obstacles; if that happens, you have to restart the stage from scratch, so keep that in mind. Even then though, you will rarely get stuck, and no stage should take you longer than 15 to 20 minutes to complete. 

Concerning the length: It´s a very short game and should not take more than two hours to complete. The only kind of collectible are crystals that you need to collect in order to unlock new story passages, and they can only be found by killing enemies and destroying hidden statues. Some of those statues are fairly well hidden, but nothing you can´t find on your first try. Otherwise, there is no replay value, no hidden bonus stuff or unlockables. Having said that, I found those two hours to be quite enjoyable and entertaining. Still, its price point (8 $) may be a bit steep for it´s overall content.

Overall, I would I recommend the game. If you feel that its price is too steep, wait until a sale occurs: At a lower price, I wholeheartily recomment it.

15558622.review:
[h1]BASIC BUT FUN[/h1]

[b]The game is enjoyable but don't get your hopes up too high.[/b]

There is a simple storyline which good enough in it's own right despite being quite basic. It serves as a simple framework for the gameplay.

The world itself is also quite simple, somewhat repetative, and it's easy to spot several places that need more work to make the gameplay more understandable and intuitive, specially with some of the puzzles. The fighting mechanics are crude yet they do their job. The game easily makes you feel there is a lack of something but if you focus on having fun it is very enjoyable. Let's just say it's easy to point out places worth improving upon. Yet this doesn't disgourage me, it makes me think of how fun it could really be with some more work.

There are a lot of interesting features and elements to this game that make it fun to play through, it packs a nice 2-3 hours of easy fun with varied tasks that offer their own unique challenges. Nothing too complex but not too simple either.


All in all I would recommend this game if you are looking for something to play around with without taking it too seriously. It gives the impression of being a basic app-game for a tablet type platform, yet left unpolished and slightly lacking. Treat it as such and you'll have fun. 

[b]Is it worth the price?[/b] No. You get a game that feels unfinished and rough with several lacking elements.

[b]Should you still buy it despite of this?[/b] If you are looking for inspiration as a game maker, or cheap fun and giggles with friends, yes.

15228948.review:
[b][u]Forward to the Sky[/u][/b] is an Action J Style platformer.

[b][u]STORY: 7/10 [/u][/b]
Personally, the story is short, sweet, and to the point. It kept me engaged as there is not much filler, or flutter, but it felt as though I was playing through a story, and my actions were of the princess. I genuinely wanted to complete the level to find out the next part of the story. As with anything, there is room to improve.

[b][u]GAMEPLAY: 7/10[/u][/b]
You play a princess in a 3rd person action platformer. The controls on the keyboard are tight, and tapping keys allow for finite jumping and a great experience. I personally had issues using the gamepad from the start, so I have no opinion if it works properly or not. The goal is to complete the level, and optionally collect all of the crystals.

[b][u]DIFFICULTY: 7/10[/u][/b]
If you plan on being an achievement completionist, you should expect this game to last you 2-3 hours for the genuine most. For me, the puzzles were not too difficult, or too easy, and I found myself having to go back and forth in some areas a few times to completely understand some of them. When you complete the puzzle, you will feel positive for completing it and continuing on. The combat of the game is lacking; you will face a handful of different skeletons with varying abilities, all will prepare you for the final boss; but the combat is weak and leaves a lot more to desire. 

[b][u]TECHNICAL: 8/10[/u][/b]
When first launching the game, the menus confused me, clicking each one of them takes you to a different part of configuration or tutorial, and eventually will start the game. I would have personally liked if the menus were a bit more intuitive. Performance was fine with a full 60fps and no dips in graphics. Some of the sounds, like a whistle for the balloon when you die can get annoying; I would prefer something a bit more lax.

[b][u]CONCLUSION [/u][/b]
Recommended gameplay for a simple platformer, with cute graphics and an engaging story. Nothing to write home about, but something you will remember playing. [b]7/10[/b]

14892690.review:
(TL;DR = Great game, albeit very short.  Needs a bit of polish, but if you like light-hearted games, hack n’ slash games, puzzle games, and/or platformers this game is definitely worth the money.)

PRO:
- Lots of gameplay elements; puzzle, hack n’ slash, and platforming.
- All gameplay elements are very well done.
- Fun, cute little story.
- Good visual style.
- Good music.
- Adorable dialog/voice acting (it’s not good, but it’s charming in how silly and earnest it is).
- No recycling; every level introduces new challenges and enemy types.
- Interesting mechanic of having to gather items on each stage to reveal more of the story.
- Full voice acting in-game.

CON:
- The combat could be deeper.
- The lack of a lock-on or ability to adjust mid-strike makes the directed attack all but useless; the game is essentially just one-button combat with the wide area attack.
 - The dodge sends you flipping backwards relative to where your character is facing, not the direction you push the left analog stick/what movement key you hit.  This makes the dodge useless as you can’t see where you are dodging and often go flipping off of a ledge.  My advice is to just jump out of the way instead.
 - It’s a bit hard to explain, but your character is sort of “floaty.”  It’s almost like she is TOO responsive; trying to land on some of the smaller platforms will often result in her running off them as you try to just adjust yourself slightly.  Maybe this had something to do with me using a controller instead of the keyboard. Regardless, my advice is to stop touching the stick/keys the moment you are about to land.
- VERY short: I was able to 100% complete it in less than two hours and in just one run.

Overall it’s a fun little game with lots of features and a sweet story.  My only complaints are that the combat is rather shallow and it is way too short.  It should be noted that there are many bad games out there that are “anime-like.”  For those games it’s clear the developers made them that way simply because they knew people would gobble them up.  That is not the case with this game; when you play it you really get the sense that Animu Game cared about their project.  Honestly, I recommend buying this game at full price like I did.  Hopefully with more money their next game can be a bit deeper and much longer.

14474681.review:
*** I used a stemkey provided by the developer for review purpose ***

Pros:
Anime flair, cutesy art
Variety of gameplay dynamics (puzzle-platformer, physics)
Solid gameplay and level design
Good voice acting
Ethereal, relaxing music

Cons:
Lack of variety of textures for game world
Limited number of enemies
Simplistic combat

Story:
FTTS is an action puzzle platformer indie game with an anime aesthetic. You play the role of a young princess, and the story goes as follows: A tower emerges on the sky of your town; Legend says that a wicked, evil witch that has oppressed your town lives in the tower. The princess decides to go up to the sky tower, on her air balloon, to confront and defeat the evil witch. The game consists of six levels, each corresponds one of the six tiers of the tower. The game plays as a storybook/fairy-tale and as you progress along the game, there will be items to be collected which will shed light on the story and will expand upon the legend.

Gameplay:
The platforming elements of the game are solid. Controls are crisp and responsive and the default controls are intuitive. The trickiest part of the controls is the free-roaming camera, which you can control at all times. Once I found the proper sensitivity setting and reversed the appropriate axes on my mouse, it became second nature in minutes. The camera allows for greater exploration of your beautiful environment and to spot possible secrets or danger areas. A few clipping bugs exist, but these are rare and not gamebreaking. If encountered, you can easily clip out of the structure in which you just clipped in.

Level/Game Design:
Each progressive level of the game introduces a new gameplay dynamic which allows the game to remain fresh. On the other hand, the combat dynamics are relatively simple and straight-forward. Attack 1 (LMB default) allows for a quick attack with your broadsword and several LMB clicks allow for doubling on your attack and following with a jumping attack. Attack 2 (RMB default) allows for a slower, more powerful attack where you charge forward with your sword. Repetitive RMB clicks lead you to perform a rapid stab maneuver, followed by a deep, powerful single stab. You can also jump out of harm's way (default spacebar) and dodge your way from danger (pressing left shift); the dodge is basically a backflip.

There are a handful of baddies which all have different attacks and timing. Combat relies on learning the patterned behaviour of your baddies and attacking them on their refractory period and avoiding head-on attacks (flanking or attacking from behind).

However, it is in the platforming where the game shines. Given the fact that each level consists of a different puzzle/platforming dynamic, part of the allure of the game relies on figuring out these dynamics while avoiding the danger that these may confer.

Difficulty of the game is low overall. There is no significant punishment or damage taken for falling of the ledge of the tower or falling down a few levels. If you fall, the young princess will dish out an inordinately strong whistle which will summon the air balloon to your rescue.

Design of the princess is intricate, cutesy with an anime-flavor. Levels are well-designed, which allow for the different game dynamics, however, given the fact that the whole game takes place in the tower, textures are relatively repetitive. The background, effects and platforming obstacles do provide some needed visual relief.

Music is relaxing, ethereal, appropriate and enjoyable. Sound effects are on point, some minimal distortion noted uncommonly
on several of the attack grunts/screams of the young princess which occur on destruction of walls/columns.

Replayability:
Overall, the game provides some mostly mindless fun. Most puzzles are simple and quickly figured out. A couple puzzles may take a few minutes to understand and solve, but complexity is basic. The game is quite fun due to the variety of game dynamics and physics. It is the puzzle platforming that shines, while the combat can be fun, but relatively monotone.

Conclusion:
Game completion should take anywhere from 2-4 hours, depending of if you rush through the game or choose to take your time and complete the achievements. Content of the game is appropriate for all ages, and the simple story behind the game and story book design is very appropriate for children. The violence is limited and safe for players of all ages. While the presentation is cutesy, the gameplay can be enjoyed by all. Game contains steam trading cards (5) and achievements (12). This is a title which can be completed to 100% achievements in a relatively short amount of time. It provides for an enjoyable experience, which feels introductory for an upcoming sequel. If you are looking for a simple, fun puzzle platformer with beautiful, cutesy art and basic difficulty, look no further than this title.

[i]If you liked this review or want to see more recommended games, be sure to follow our curator group: [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Original_Curators_Group#curation]Follow Original Curator Group[/url][/i]

14419140.review:
[h1]Really short but entirely worth it[/h1]

The game has a light but overall enjoyable story surrounded by platforming puzzles with simple but workable combat. The platforming consists of making simple jumps with the meat of it being positioning platforms to progress to either the next section of a level (there are only 6 levels in all) or for a side area.

The premise of each level is to either reach the end or collect 100 crystals before the end to unlock a side story. Crystals are obtained from enemies or smashing statues. Enemies range from melee, range, and magic and come in different levels themselves: minion, veteran, boss (not official names). With the simple combat it means for some groups you'll have to employ strategy to defeat a group at times as you cannot replenish lost life in a level and later groups can mob you to death if you just rush in blindly.

It's a quirky fun game but once you full clear the six levels there isn't much reason to go back to it, still I had a lot of fun with the game and can recommend it.

14413844.review:
There isn't a lot of complexity to this short yet simple indie action puzzle platformer and yet, it has still managed to enthrall me as I progressed from level to level, puzzle to puzzle.

Forward to the Sky is a very charming third person adventure game where you control a princess (whose design is very reminiscent of Saber Lily's from Fate/Unlimited Codes) as you attempt to scale the floating sky tower and confront the evil witch, or so it goes. 

Each level features a different game mechanic that a player has to use in order to solve the puzzles and move on as well as find secret areas that will allow you to collect all 100 crystals in that level. While the puzzles may not be overly complex, they are hard enough that gives you that 'Aha!' moment once you solve them and yet are forgiving enough that I don't think anyone will ever feel frustrated with any of them. In that sense, to anyone who has played a Zelda game, Forward to the Sky is pretty similar in regards to its puzzles.

While the voice acting may seem a bit lackluster and the main menu may be a bit cryptic, it more than makes up for it with the aforementioned puzzles, satisfying gameplay, the simple yet adorable art style reminiscent once again to old Zelda games, serene music, responsive controls and its fairy tale charm.

With all that said, would I recommend this game? Of course!

14397579.review:
www.youtube.com/watch?v=d6yRqzQm6H0

	Forward to the Sky is a third person action adventure with platforming 
elements and an anime feel.  Graphically the game is sound, and the music does a good job of propelling the atmosphere and the momentum through the story. The game is based around climbing a tower, and there are only six levels to the tower, making the total game time between 1 1/2 and 3 hours. As you ascend the tower, you collect crystals on each level that drop from killing monsters or solving a puzzle.  

	The gameplay is simplistic, and what combat there is, is not the selling
point of this game.  You are given the option to kill all the enemies, or bypass them, if that is not your thing.  You can make your own path if you wish
to.  I feel that the story was overdone, and a lot of it is unnecessary filler.  
When the dialogue happens, the text takes up a large portion of the screen and limits your view.  That coupled with  all the extra story got to be annoying.  

	What makes this story interesting is the level design.  Each level offers
new, interesting mechanics, making each level unique and keeping the player
involved.  It keeps the gameplay fresh.  The level design offers freedom, with an  open feel that allows the player to bypass parts of the level if they choose.  

	Overall, the combat is sufficient, there is a large variety of puzzles and
level design mechanics that adds to the possibility of replay, and I never felt
as if the time I put into the game wasted my time.  It respected me as a player, and I enjoyed my time in it.  I would have liked to see more levels, but overall this was an enjoyable adventure.  

This is a summary of my review video, which I encourage you to watch
if you are looking for a more in-depth review.

14387078.review:
Pros
- Fun action
- Okto good puzzles (if you are looking to collect all the crystals)

Neither pro or con
- Many "puzzles" aren't...they are timed jump "puzzles"
- Short game, but for the cost of entry its about right.
- Supports gamepad...and looks like it would play better with one but I felt it was easier using mouse/keyboard

Cons
- Short game if you just play through to the end.

   The game starts off telling you that there are 100 crystals per level (6 levels total) to collect on your way to fight the "Witch." The entire game takes place on "The Tower." The Tower is a collection of blocks hovering in the air, if you fall you die.  Don't worry too much about falling though cause you will be respawned and flown back in to someplace nearish to where you fell.  
   I honestly think that this game would have been more fun if it was a little more old school and sent you back to the start when you fall off the world. That said...
   Most of the puzzles are pretty striaght forward to solve. The more annoying ones are the timed jump "puzzles" but they are easily overcome since the game restarts you near to where you failed, or has a route you can take to retry it again and again till you get it right.

Summary:
   Tagging this game as an RPG is WAY off imo. For starters, there is no character development or anything of that nature.  It's a pure 3D platformer in an anime style.  It is easy to play through the game in about 2 hours if you are not looking to collect all the crystals. This is where the game makes up for its short play through time somewhat, but for 8USD its not overpriced.

14365155.review:
Forward to the Sky has 6 levels, a weak but family-friendly story, simple combat, and can be finished to 100% in under 2 hours.
However, it is beautiful, controls well with keyboard and mouse, and features some really enjoyable 3D platforming puzzles with new gimmicks introduced in each level.

For combat, you have two combos that are each activated by repeatedly pressing a single button. However, there is still a good amount of enemy variety that keeps things from getting too repetetive. The game also features a multi-stage final boss in which you have to figure out how to defeat each unique part. I tend to prefer combat to be simple in my platformers, so I like the system used in Forward to the Sky, but those who want combat with lots of depth will not find it here.

The goal in each level is easy enough to reach, but there are plenty of hidden areas to reach and plunder to get to 100%. Figuring out how to get to the secret areas tends to take a bit of thought, but not so much that I spent more than a few minutes on any of them which leads to a satisfying experience all throughout the game. The game is short, but it is entertaining from start to finish.

14328582.review:
Forward to the Sky is a simple, charming, lovely action adventure game that's short and sweet. There isn't much to talk about it, but here we go.

The look of the game is quite decent, and somewhat beautiful, in a sense of PlayStation 2 type of graphical and artistic beauty, and actually, the gameplay and design of the game has a nice relating feeling of the type of games of that time, but built with today's tech, and I'm okay with it because the game was built sort-of nicely.

The voice acting is cute and nice, in fact the whole game is cute and nice, with the story being simple and told in a simple way too, slowly revealing the pieces of that story, but one could say it's predictable, but for me I don't mind predictability in games as long as the the story, or the way it's presented, is bad, which it isn't in this game.

The only bad things about the game are its not so great combat controls, playable and manageable, but noticeably basic, and that's what I can think of that was a con in the game.

The puzzle solving & platforming in the game aren't hard either, mostly fun simple ones that require a little bit of effort to finish/figure-out, and the whole game isn't hard either, it's as I said mostly in this whole write-up, it's a simple game with simple mechanics, that's lovely and a charm to play through, and for the price, I'd be happy to recommend it.

14307154.review:
tl;tr - It was cute and sweet, but sadly short. Beautiful graphics and detail. 9/10 would buy again.

I first purchased the game because the cuteness got me. I was not disappointed. It was quite adorable with a sweet storyline that you uncover as you go. While it is a bit short, it isn't half bad compared to other indie games out there. Especially since it is (i think) the company's first game. But, lets get to the niddy-griddy.

Pros:
It was fairly easy to dive into, you don't have to deal with a tutorial. The graphics are quite beautiful and interesting. The story was good, if not a bit obvious to me. However, it is the characters that make the story, not the story itself. Voice acting was pretty good as well.

Neutral Statements:
The main menu was a bit odd, since it didn't say what each thing was and was only an Icon. But that isn't anything major. (The menu itself was good looking too) There wasn't much combat, and most of it was easy once you got the controls down. The puzzles are relatively easy if you think about them for a few minutes, but as a game that can easily be rated E, thats to be expected. 

Cons:
It was short. Took me roughly 1.5 hours to complete. (But, for $8, i feel i got my moneys worth) There is a lack of replayability, as once you complete it nothing really changes from each playthrough, unless you miss crystals going through the levels. (but then again, almost every game has almost 0% replayability for me anyway, lol) The "flying" stuff is kind of wonky. It can be hard to use if you aren't prepared.

Honestly, i'm excited to see where they go from here and look forward to the company's future games. I can easily give it a 9/10.

14306510.review:
For me the art style of the game was the selling point. When I started the game up I got what I expected for the price: Simple combat, nice and sometimes challenging puzzling and some platforming elements. The controls are tight but sometimes frustrating when jumping. Combat consists of slamming the left or right mouse button to swing your sword, you cannot block, you can only "dodge". It's very minimal.

The game contains 6 levels/chapters, in each of which a new, unique mechanic is introduced, which I like.  The dialogue is sometimes funny but overall very naively written, what makes it obvious that the game was targeted at children. Though that doesn't mean you cannot enjoy the game as an adult, because I did. It's a nice little game.

But why am I not recommending it? It's the unjustified price. It took me 1.4 hours to finish 100% of the game (all "collectibles") for 7.99€, which isn't worth it at all. I Can only recommend to pick it up on a lower price.

14304847.review:
Forward to the sky is a short and sweet game, even shorter if you don't intend to collect all the gems. The game will take you on a 1-2 hours journey as you slash your way through enemies while traversing through light platforming segments and puzzles. Though combat can get repetitive this is mitagated by the introduction of new elements throughout the levels such as wind tunnels, gravity, and more. 

The game uses a chibi/cute anime style which may be off putting to some. While the music isn't very memorable it does it's job and suits the atmoesphere of the game. The voice acting on the other hand will be hit or miss for some. As while it is by no means awful it's certaintly nothing to write home about. At the very least it isn't as bad as some anime dubs I have seen. 

Overall the game is an enjoyable time but some consideration should be put into whether it's worth the $8 considering it's fairly short length and fairly minimal replay value. As well as it's fairly easy difficulty, which a child could beat. This may be a good or bad point for you.

I would recommend buying this game on sale, but if you're craving a light-hearted anime game then you certainly can't go wrong with this one.

Here's a link to my review: http://youtu.be/DXz6CknBx9U
